text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ y/o woman with STEMI and total RCA occlusion s/p DES complicated by post-infarct ventricular septal perforation. # STEMI: Pt had 100% RCA occlusion just distal to the acute marginal takeoff, now s/p DES with restoration of flow to the distal RCA and PDA (R dominant). She was started on ASA, Plavix, Atorvastatin, metoprolol and lisinopril during her hospital course. ___ showed mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with severe hypokinesis of the basal half of the inferior and inferolateral walls. Immediately following PCI she was in 2:1 heart block, which subsequently evolved to Wenckebach and 1:1 conduction. She remained hemodynamically stable throughout and was discharged home with cardiology and PCP follow up. # VSD: Physical exam on admission to the CCU revealed a new III/VI systolic murmur heard thoughout the precordium concerning for new VSD/MR. ___ showed VSD, cardiac MRI later showed 3:1 shunt fraction, normal RV size with free wall hypokinesis and elevated PA pressures. Her O2 sat remained >93% on RA throughout her course and she was given diuresis for reducing pulmonary edema and shunt, and minimizing pulmonary hypertension. Blood pressure was also optimized to decrease afterload and maximize forward flow. The definite treatment will require surgical repair of the interventricular septum defect. Percutaneous VSD closure may also be an option. OUTPATIENT ISSUES: - F/U WITH CT SURGERY/INTERVENTIONAL CARDIOLOGY - Adjust lasix 80 mg po qd - Should have RHC to assess shunt function which could help decide whether patient needs to have her shunt fixed # A-fib: Pt was found to have a period of unsustained symptomatic A-fib, lasting ~30 mins. This could be a result of changes in RA volume and dynamics. Given patient's already compromised CO, atrial kick is necessary to maintain adequate MAP. Amiodarone was started for rhythm control. She was continued on metoprolol for rate control. CHRONIC DIAGNOSES: DM: Pt has documented hx of diabetes, controlled by Pioglitizone prior to admission. She was covered with ISS during this hospitalization. She was restarted on pioglitizone prior to discharge. # HTN - Her home Verapamil was held and she was started on Metoprolol and Lisinopril with SBP goal in the ___ given the lack of mortality benefit of CCB (especially verapamil) # GERD - Patient has a documented history of GERD, and takes omeprazole at home. Omeprazole was stopped in setting of plavix while ranitidine was started at 150 mg po qhs. # HLD: She was started on atorvastatin 80 mg po qdaily (PROVE trial) but it was decreased to 40 mg po qdaily given she was on multiple medications (amiodarone) which would uptitrate her statin dose putting her at risk for rhabdomyolysis. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: - Pt maintained a full code during this admission - Pt has follow up with Dr. ___ in one week and CT surgery in 2 weeks
summary: You were transferred to our hospital for treatment of a heart attack. The blockage in your arteries was opened and a stent was placed in one of your coronary arteries to help keep it open. We also treated you with several medications to reduce the risk of both another heart attack and of your heart becoming weak from having had a heart attack. Your heart also suffered a complication from your heart attack in which one of the walls between the different chambers of your heart ruptured, allowing blood to flow in a direction it normally would not flow. This is a serious complication and requires repair. You were evaluated by our interventional cardiologists as well as our cardiac surgeons who felt that it would be best to postpone correcting this problem until you have had a bit more time to recover from your heart attack. We have changed some of your medications and started you on several new medications.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ y/o M with no significant PMH presents to the ED with palpitations likely ___ hyperthyroidism. . # Palpitations: Onset 4 days prior to admission. ___ enzymes neg x 2, EKG showed sinus tach, unlikely PE as d-dimer negative. Normal CXR so no pulm process. Constellation of sinus tachycardia, palpitations, and TSH<0.02, Free T4 3.9, T3 354, consistent with hyperthyroidism. Propranolol 20 mg TID was started which helped reduce patient's HR and provide symptomatic relief. - Anti-TPO pending at discharge to eval for ___'s (***returned high at 204 IU/mL, upper limit normal 35). . # Leg pain: Patient had presented with vague joint aches in his legs, potentially consistent with a viral illness, which he reported having over the past week, but had resolved. D-dimer negative, also not consistent with DVT symptoms. By morning of admission, patient was asymptomatic, with no more leg pain. . # Elevated LFTs: Likely ___ hyperthyroidism - has been known to show increase in AlkP, and rarely cholestasis. -needs follow up LFTs
summary: You were admitted to ___ for palpitations. Blood tests showed that this was because of a disorder called "hyperthyroidism" - an overactive thyroid. We started you on a medicine to help with the palpitations, but you need to follow up with an endocrinologist in outpatient to address the underlying disease. Your palpitations decreased during your stay.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ASSESSMENT & PLAN: ___ woman h/o HTN, heart block s/p pacemaker, hyperlipidemia, ___, GERD, CKD stage III, adrenal mass with ___ syndrome, glaucoma, obesity admitted with elevated LFT s/p ERCP with placement of biliary/pancreatic stents. Also with worsening controlled diabetes over last two weeks for unclear reasons with progressive generalized weakness and unsteady gait. # Elevated LFTs, Choledocholithiasis: Unclear reason for elevated LFT. Had stones but not obstructive on the ERCP. Due to difficult passage of ERCP, there is concern for head of pancreas mass as an etiology. She was transferred to floor and was clinically stable s/p ERCP with biliary stent placement. She was asymptomatic, tolerated a regular diet, and was treated with ciprofloxacin. Cytology from brush bx is presently pending. CEA mildly elevated, CA ___ is pending at the time of discharge. She is scheduled for an EUS-ERCP on ___ for stent removal and possible bx for head of pancreas if the cytology was unrevealing. Her LFTs showed steady improvement during this hospitalization. # ___, uncontrolled with complications: She was noted to have recent worsening in hyperglycemia. This may be secondary to ___ syndrome, for which she was evaluated by Urology Dr ___ in ___, thought surgical risk too high at this time. She has a very high insulin requirements, which she takes regularly, denies dietary indiscretion (actually reports anorexia with weight loss). During this hospitalization, she had volatile BS during this stay - likely due to multiple factors: resolution of biliary obstruction, erratic kidney function (now nl Cr), recent wt loss, and most importantly ___ sx. Last TSH 0.62 (___). ___/ Endocrinology was consulted who recommended very specific changes in her insulin dosing (see discharge orders). The decision to use mifepristone or ketoconazole for treatment of adrenal hormone issue (HTN, hyperglycemia) will be deferred for her outpt endocrinologist. We may need to reeval the candidacy for lap adrenalectomy as an outpt, since she did not have any evidence of significant respiratory difficulties and was able to ambulate without much difficulty. Endocrinology recommended holding byetta, glipizide until her follow up with Dr. ___. # Pruritus: likely due to biliary stasis. Has occurred prior to administration of abx. Benadryl PRN. # hyponatremia: partially hypertonic secondary to hyperglycemia, also component of hypovolemia. Improved with hydration. Now within normal limits # DOE: needs evaluation; currently no evidence CHF. Nl TTE in ___ - no evidence of dyspnea during this hospitalization # HTN: still hypertensive. Concern that ___ an etiology for the hypertension. - Cont clonidine, labetalol, nifedipine CR, spironolactone, and ___ # heart block s/p pacemaker: no acute issues # hyperlipidemia: stable, continue colesevelam # CKD stage III: stable - renally dose all meds # GERD: stable, continue PPI #DVT PROPHYLAXIS: heparin sc #CODE STATUS: full code
summary: You were admitted after obtaining an ERCP to help relieve the biliary obstruction. A stone was identified in the common bile duct and removed. Two stents were placed - one in the pancreatic duct and the other in the common bile duct. The cause of the biliary duct is at present unclear. A sample was sent for analysis and should return sometime next week.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Pt arrived to the floor complaining of ongoing ___ chest pain. An EKG was obtained during the chest pain which showed no significant changes from prior EKGs. The patient's pain was found to be reproducable by exam. Pt was ruled out for MI with 3 negative cardiac enzymes and then underwent a P-MIBI which showed a mild reversible inferolateral defect that was new since the patient's last stress test. After discussion with the patient's physician, ___ was made for patient to undergo catheterization due to his concern for angina. The cath showed no significant coronary artery disease. The patient's elevated creatinine was worked up and he was diagnosed with chronic kidney disease given the elevated creatinine for ___ year and the lack of improvement with significant fluid rescuscitation. The patient was watched overnight to check his creatinine which was 1.3 in the morning. The patient's chest pain was resolved by the morning. His groin site showed no hematoma, no tenderness, no bruit with 2+ DP and femoral pulses. The patient was discharged chest pain free and in stable condition with plan for follow up with Dr. ___.
summary: You were admitted with chest pain and underwent a stress test that showed some abnormalities. However, you also underwent cardiac catheterization that showed your stents are still open, and therefore negative for significant coronary artery disease. Based on that, there was no need for intervention. Based on our clinical impression, the most likely cause for your chest pain is musculoskeletal. Our tests did show that you have mild chronic kidney disease (with a estimated GFR of 51) that did not improve with fluids. You should discuss this with Dr. ___ as well as your primary care physician.

text: Brief Hospital Course: The patient is a ___ otherwise healthy man with 5 days of fever, HA, nausea of as yet unknown etiology, with bland CSF (1 WBC) of low concern for aseptic meningitis, now with finding of RLL PNA on CT with mild cough but absence of other respiratory symptoms being treated with doxycycline and levofloxacin. #FEVER/COMMUNITY-ACQUIRED PNEUMONIA - At presentation, the patient's fevers to 102-103 in the setting of severe headache were concerning for meningitis. He was evaluated by neurology, however, CSF with 1WBC was not concerning for meningeal infection. Workup revealed mildly positive UA with elevated protein and spec ___, but negative nitrites and leukocyte esterase; in the absence of dysuria UTI was thought very unlikely. The patient was evaluated by infectious disease and an extensive workup was sent for tick-borne illnesses and arboviruses; this revealed neg Lyme, HIV, Ehrlichia, EBV, CMV, CSF gram stain and culture, with further tests (Rickettsia, Leptospira) pending. The patient was started on a 14-day course of IV doxycycline as empiric treatment for tick-borne bacterial illness. CXR in the ED revealed subtle RLL infiltrate and ___ LAD, however since he was without cough or other respiratory symptoms and with good O2 sat on room air, pulmonary infection was thought unlikely. When his fevers, headache, and nausea had not significant improved on the doxycycline by HD2, he underwent non-contrast chest CT as follow-up for his CXR. This revealed a dense RLL pneumonia with reactive mediastinal LAD. He was started on a 7-day course of IV levofloxacin for community-acquired pneumonia. He was unable to produce an induced sputum sample without oropharyngeal contamination. He developed a mild cough but his respiratory status otherwise remained stable and his fever curve trended downwards and by discharge he had been afebrile for over 36 hours. Blood cultures x4 and urine cultures x2 remained negative. He was transitioned to PO antibiotics with planned total course of levofloxacin for 7 days (last day ___ and doxycycline for 14 days (last day ___ and discharged home afebrile and in stable condition. #HEADACHE - The patient was admitted to the service with severe headache, thought to be mainly post-LP headache combined with effects of his illness and fever. He had initially complained of photophobia on admission but this quickly resolved. His pain was controlled with alternating IV morphine and IV dilaudid along with Fioricet, with care not to exceed maximum doses allowed for his renal impairment and transaminitis. Dilaudid was ultimately discontinued as it was contributing to his nausea and vomiting. Once he was taking POs, he was transitioned to oxycodone and fioricet. He had initially complained of increased pain with sitting up, so anesthesia was called for potential blood patch for post-LP headache, however they were reluctant to do this while he was febrile. His headache improved on oxycodone and fioricet and he rated it as ___ before discharge. He was discharged home with 10 tablets of 5mg oxycodone along with acetaminophen for residual headache. It is anticipated that his headache will continue to improve overtime, and he was advised to take narcotics only when necessary and to taper use of it to prevent potential rebound headache. #ACUTE RENAL FAILURE: The patient presented with increased Creatinine to 2.1 (baseline 1.05 -1.3) likely due to intravascular volume depletion/pre-renal given low FeNa, ___ several days of nausea and vomiting and decreased PO intake. In addition, he was found to have elevated CK. Patient was given IVF while in the hospital. His Cr improved over the course of admission to 1.3. Renally cleared medications were minimized during his admission and he had good urine output throughout his stay. He was adviced to avoid taking the OTC supplement while he continues to have ARF. #TRANSAMINITIS - The patient presented with a mild transaminitis of ALT 115 AST 79 (baseline: normal LFTs) and normal TBili, with subsequent improvement to AST and ALT in the ___. The patient initial mild RUQ tenderness which quickly resolved. He had a negative viral hepatitis panel, mildly elevated ferritin to 531 (likely acute phase reaction), and negative ___ and ANCA. RUQ ultrasound was unremarkable except for one 9mm hepatic cyst. The elevation in enzymes was thought likely due to regular home use of several supplements, the safety profiles of which are unknown. The patient's ALT and AST remained generally stable throughout admission. He was recommended to avoid taking his OTC supplements while he continues to have transaminitis to avoid potential further injury. #RHABDOMYOLYSIS. Likely related to the underlying infectious etiology. Improved with fluid hydration. #NAUSEA - The patient had significant nausea throughout his hospital stay, likely ___ PNA and fever, and later thought to be aggravated by IV hydromorphone that was used for headache. His nausea was treated with IV ondansetron and phenergan and PR prochlorperazine with good response. His diet was slowly advanced and by discharge he was tolerating solid food. He was discharged with PO ondansetron and promethazine for residual nausea at home. Chronic issues: None Transitional issues: #FOLLOW-UP: -___ was contacted on the day of patient's discharge to inform of the hospital course as well as the importance to have follow up for patient given his lab abnormalities (stable and slowly improving) and headache. -Primary care: Patient indicated that he no longer sees primary care care at ___. Instead, he reports seeing ___ at ___. He was instructed to call ___ on ___ after discharge to set up urgent care follow up given the recent hospitalization. He will need to have repeat labs to monitor for his renal function as well as liver function. He was informed that his primary care provider ___ assess his headache to determine the next step of action for management.
summary: You were admitted to the ___ on ___ for fever, headache, and nausea. You were evaluated by neurology, who performed a lumbar puncture which showed low suspicion for meningitis, however, there was suspicion that your symptoms were caused by a a viral infection or an infection that you could have contracted from a tick bite or mosquito bite. Testing was sent off for these possible viral illnesses and you were started on the antibiotic doxycycline. A chest x-ray done when you were admitted showed enlarged lymph nodes, and a follow-up CT scan of your chest revealed a pneumonia (lung infection) in the right lung. You were started on the antibiotic levofloxacin to treat a community-acquired pneumonia. Your fever, headache, and nausea have improved. You will be going home on doxycycline for a total of 14 days and levofloxacin for a total of 7 days. You should avoid taking over the counter supplements given recent liver and kidney injury. You should avoid drinking alcohol until your liver returns to normal. You should avoid taking medications such as ibuprofen, Motrin, Aleve, etc.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ y/o female with PMHx significant for HTN, HLD, diet-controlled type II diabetes, GERD, and hemochromatosis originally presented to ___ today with 1 hour anterior chest pain radiating through to her back and her left arm and was transferred to BID for cardiac cath found to have 3VD with mid-distal RCA acute occlusion now s/p 3DES to RCA found to have regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction c/w CAD. Mildly dilated right ventricular cavity with preserved systolic function. Moderate mitral regurgitation. Elevated PCWP. She was started on ASA, Plavix and Atorvastatin. She was hypotensive and bradycardic post-procedure, and required a dopamine gtt and Atropine overnight in the CCU. She was transferred to the floor, and remained hemodynamically stable throughout her stay. Her EKGs and labs were monitored daily. Her Propanolol (for essential tremors- she does not wish to change BB) was decreased from 20 to 10 mg bid in setting of ongoing bradycardia. Cleared by physical therapy for discharge; She was discharged in stable condition; family aware of diagnosis/plan
summary: You were transferred from ___ to ___ after you presented there with a myocardial infarction (heart attack). You had a heart catheterization, which showed blockages in your right coronary artery. Three stents were placed to open the blockage, and improve blood flow to your heart. You were started on Aspirin and Plavix. Aspirin and Plavix are used to decrease the risk of clot formation in your stent. You will take Aspirin indefinitely, and Plavix for at least one year. Do not stop taking Plavix until told to do so only by your Cardiologist. Stopping Plavix prematurely may increase your risk of a life threatening heart attack. After your procedure, your heart rate and blood pressure were unstable, so you were closely monitored overnight in the CCU. You were transferred out to the floor when you were stable. You were also started on Atorvastatin to manage your heart disease and cholesterol. Your lipid panel and liver function will be monitored periodically.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ hx pAFib (on dabigatran), hypothyroidism, bronchiectasis, and dementia with behavioral disturbances admitted from ___ for reported change in behavior/mental status (refusing medications and less interactive), found to have diffuse GGO on CT chest and possible UTI. # AMS # UTI: Patient admitted overnight from ___ assisted living facility. Per the staff and there patient was recently returned from rehab noted to be refusing medications. For this reason was sent into hospital for concerns of altered mental status. No fevers or other focal symptoms were noted prehospital. CT chest with some GGOs as well as urinalysis with pyuria/bacteriuria. When patient arrived in the floor interview with her husband who sees her daily caretaker adjusted that not unusual behavior for Mrs. ___ Mr. ___ she was at her baseline mental status. As result it was thought that her behavioral change was part of her overall cognitive decline (see below) Culture eventually grew E. coli with moderate resistance pattern. She had been empirically treated with cefepime was changed to nitrofurantoin based on culture results, with a 7-day course to be completed on ___ ___. She was evaluated by ___ recommended ___ rehab. After discussion with Mr. ___, patient was discharged to a rehab facility. # Diffuse ground glass opacities and RUL consolidation: Although patient did not have any respiratory complaints, was not hypoxic chest demonstrated some GGOs the pulmonary fields. Given her elevated BNP and pulmonary congestion seen on CXR and slightly elevated BNP, this likely represents fluid. Patient was given 10 mg IV Lasix ×1 on HD #1. Do not have any further respiratory complaints, cough, hypoxia, or tachypnea while hospitalized. Echocardiogram was normal function and valve function. She will likely require follow-up imaging in the outpatient setting. # Dementia with behavioral disturbances: Patient had been on risperidone for behavioral disturbances and insomnia until last month when she developed EPS. Subsequently started on divalproex PRN sundowning, but it appears this was not continued on her most recent medication list. Given the burden on her family required for her care she appears that she is unable to thrive at an assisted living facility would likely benefit from long-term placement at a dementia/behavioral unit. CHRONIC/STABLE PROBLEMS: # Paroxysmal AFib: Remained in rate-controlled AFib while hospitalized. Home dabigitran adndiltiazem were continued. # Hypothyroidism: Continued home levothyroxine. # Major depressive disorder: Continued home citalopram.
summary: You were admitted to the hospital because it was felt that ___ were not acting like herself at your home. ___ were evaluated with blood tests and tests x-rays and CAT scans. He was diagnosed with having extra fluid inside the lungs and urinary tract infectionYou were treated with medications to remove the fluid from your lungs as well as IV and oral antibiotics to treat your infection. However, in discussion with her family do not believe the symptoms that originally brought ___ to the hospital are due to the infection or lung fluid. Rather we believe this is part of your overall process. He will likely require further assistance with daily activities of living in the near future. He will be discharged to complete a course of an antibiotic called nitrofurantoin also known as Macrobid.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Ms. ___ is a very pleasant ___ yo female with no known PMHx who presents on transfer from ___ where she came on night of ___ with altered mental status and was found to have profound leukocytosis and anemia. At that time, her WBC count was 397, HgB 3.3, LDH 781, haptoglobin <10 and she was transferred to ___ MICU for further treatment. She was treated with high dose steroids and 4 U pRBCs as well as rasburicase and allopurinol for hyperuricemia. She did not receive plasmaphoresis in the MICU, as it is likely that her AMS was due to profound anemia rather than leukostasis. Troponins were also positive in the ICU which is thought to be most consistent with type II NSTEMI in the setting of profound anemia. CT abdomen revealed diffuse lymphadenopathy. Peripheral smear and flow cytometry were consistent with new diagnosis of chronic lymphocytic leukemia. Direct coombs was positive for IgG (3+), warm hemolytic anemia. G6PD negative. She has been treated with Rituxan (beginning ___ and Bendamustine (beginning ___ as well as high dose steroids. Hemolysis labs (LD and Tbili) have subsequently improved and we have started to taper her steroids. Her hyperuricemia has also resolved with treatment and allopurinol discontinued. Additionally, while admitted she began complaining of increased pain in lower extremities, so a Doppler U/S was ordered. U/S on ___ showed completely occlusive thrombus within the left popliteal vein and also areas of thrombosis bilaterally in the calf veins. Patient had not been on prophylactic anticoagulation previously due to thrombocytopenia. There was some concern that this thrombosis was secondary to HIT but heparin antibodies are negative. She received 2 days of Fondaparinux while HIT was a consideration. Once workup was negative she was started on Lovenox BID.
summary: You were admitted to ___ when you were found to be confused and more tired than normal at home. There, your red blood cell count was very low and you were transferred to ___ for further treatment. Here, we found that you have leukemia. Leukemia is a disease which causes your body to make too many white blood cells which don't work correctly. These abnormal white blood cells can cause your body to start breaking down your red blood cells. This is why you had such a low red blood cell count when you came into the hospital. To treat your leukemia we gave you two medications through your veins called Rituximab and Bendamustine. You tolerated these medications very well. These medicines have helped decrease the number of abnormal white blood cells that you have in your blood. We also gave you steroids. These steroids have slowed down the your body from breaking down your red blood cells. You still are breaking down your red blood cells, but much more slowly than when you came into the hospital.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Mrs. ___ is a ___ w/ h/o UC s/p lap proctocolectomy, J pouch, anal anastomosis w/ diverting loop ileostomy (___) s/p ileostomy takedown (___) p/w pSBO ___ episode). Given this history she was admitted, made NPO (did not require a NGT) and taken to the operating room on ___ for a Laparoscopic lysis of adhesions. She tolerated the procedure well without complications (Please see operative note for further details). After a brief and uneventful stay in the PACU, the patient was transferred to the floor for further post-operative management. Neuro: Pain was well controlled on made medications CV: Vital signs were routinely monitored during the patient's length of stay. Pulm: The patient was encouraged to ambulate, sit and get out of bed, use the incentive spirometer, and had oxygen saturation levels monitored as indicated. GI: The patient was initially kept NPO after the procedure. The patient was later advanced to and tolerated a regular diet at time of discharge. GU: Patient had a Foley catheter that was removed at time of discharge. Urine output was monitored as indicated. At time of discharge, the patient was voiding without difficulty. ID: The patient's vital signs were monitored for signs of infection and fever. The patient was started on/continued on antibiotics as indicated. Heme: The patient had blood levels checked post operatively during the hospital course to monitor for signs of bleeding. The patient had vital signs, including heart rate and blood pressure, monitored throughout the hospital stay. On ___ (HD 4, POD 2), the patient was discharged to home. At discharge, she was tolerating a regular diet, passing flatus, stooling, voiding, and ambulating independently. She will follow-up in the clinic in ___ weeks. This information was communicated to the patient directly prior to discharge. Include in Brief Hospital Course for Every Patient and check of boxes that apply: Post-Surgical Complications During Inpatient Admission: [ ] Post-Operative Ileus resolving w/o NGT [ ] Post-Operative Ileus requiring management with NGT [ ] UTI [ ] Wound Infection [ ] Anastomotic Leak [ ] Staple Line Bleed [ ] Congestive Heart failure [ ] ARF [ ] Acute Urinary retention, failure to void after Foley D/C'd [ ] Acute Urinary Retention requiring discharge with Foley Catheter [ ] DVT [ ] Pneumonia [ ] Abscess [x] None Social Issues Causing a Delay in Discharge: [ ] Delay in organization of ___ services [ ] Difficulty finding appropriate rehab hospital disposition. [ ] Lack of insurance coverage for ___ services [ ] Lack of insurance coverage for prescribed medications. [ ] Family not agreeable to discharge plan. [ ] Patient knowledge deficit related to ileostomy delaying dispo [x] No social factors contributing in delay of discharge.
summary: You were admitted to the hospital for a small bowel obstruction. Given that this was your ___ partial small bowel obstruction s/p lap proctocolectomy, J pouch, anal anastomosis w/ diverting loop ileostomy (___) s/p ileostomy takedown (___), you were taken to the operating room for a laparoscopic lysis of adhesions. Your obstruction has subsequently resolved.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Ms ___ is a ___ with a complex medical history significant for CAD (s/p CABG), aortic and mitral valve replacement x 2, and TVR with bioprosthetic valves in ___, HFrEF (EF ___, Afib, T2DM, HTN, and a hx of gastritis, who was admitted from her rehab facility with melanotic stools and a downtrending Hgb. On presentation anticoagulation for AF was held due to hemodynamic instability. She presented with a Hgb of 7.0 and ultimately required 2 prbc transfusions over her hospitalization. Capsule study, following unremarkable EGD/colonoscopy (no source of bleed), revealed erosions and shallow ulceration in the stomach antrum similar to the EGD findings. Patient was restarted on her anticoagulation 3 days prior to discharge and remained hemodynamically stable with no further melena. ACUTE ISSUES ============ #Acute blood loss anemia: #GI Bleeding: Patient initially presented to ___ with intermittent bloody/melenic stools and a Hgb of 6.2 where she received 1U PRBCs, 2U FFP, and vitamin K. On transfer to ___ Hgb was 7.0. Patient was transfused a total of 2 units prbc during her hospitalization and has not required further transfusions since ___. She was continued on IV PPI and underwent EGD/Colonscopy that revealed ulcers at the gastroesophageal junction and in the stomach (that may explain bleeding), as well as diverticulosis of the sigmoid and descending colon. Capsule study revealed erosions and shallow ulceration in the stomach antrum similar to the EGD findings, although the capsule did not leave the stomach for duration of the study. On discharge, hemoglobin was stable at 7.5. #Delayed sternal wound healing: Patient had repeat AVR/MVR as well as TVR in ___, complicated by delayed sternal wound healing requiring debridement at that time. Patient was seen by cardiac surgery on present admission who recommended wet to dry dressing changes for the 9cm wound. Patient should have wound vac placed at rehab. #Afib: Patient is on coumadin for her AF. After much discussion with patient and family, a decision was made to hold anticoagulation in the setting of active bleeding (and bioprosthetic valves not requiring anticoagulation). Patient's anticoagulation was restarted on ___, as she was hemodynamic stable with no further episodes of melena. Her INR on discharge was 1.2. CHRONIC ISSUES ============== #Thrombocytopenia: Stable. #Hypothyroidism: Stable. continued home levothyroxine. #Insomnia: Stable. continued home ramelteon #CAD s/p CABG: Stable. continued home pravastatin and ASA. #DM: Stable. Continued on insulin sliding scale. while inpatient TRANSITIONAL ISSUES =================== []Patient was restarted on her home warfarin regimen of 4mg M, W, F and 3mg T, TR, ___ on ___. Her INR was 1.2 on discharge and will need to be rechecked on ___. Goal INR is ___. []Patient will need wound vac placed for delayed sternal wound healing. Continue wet to dry dressing changes TID and ensure patient is wearing a bra until wound vac can be placed. [] Patient's Hb at discharge was 7.5. Please repeat CBC within ___ days of discharge to ensure this is stable to increasing. [] If clinically warranted or concern for ongoing GI bleed, consider repeat capsule study. In-house capsule study did not capture beyond the stomach for duration of study
summary: You were admitted from your rehab facility because you had blood in your stool You received a blood transfusion because your counts were too low. We temporarily stopped your blood thinner because we were concerned about your bleeding. This was restarted after your blood counts seemed to stabilize. You had an endoscopy and colonoscopy done to try and find the source of your bleeding. These tests did not find the cause of your bleeding. You then underwent a capsule study which found a few shallow ulcers in your stomach. This study may need to be repeated in the future. You should return to the hospital if you notice any more blood in your stool.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ with neurofibromatosis 1 with malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor of L lower leg in ___ s/p radiation and surgical resection, recently diagnosed new pancreatic mass and lung nodules in ___ s/p biopsy consistent with MPNST now s/p C1 AIM admitted now with chest pain most likely GERD and hiccup related, ruled out PE. # Chest pain: His symptoms were most consistent with a primary GI process such as GERD and esophageal spasm especially since this occurred after significant hiccups. While suspicion was low for a PE the patient was tachcyardic to the 120s with dyspnea and has active malignancy and a recent hospitalization for chemotherapy so V/Q performed (ARF on admission) which ruled out PE. Started on PPI and Maalox with improvement in symptoms. # Hiccups: New onset after chemo administration, continuous and refractory. Attempted Reglan, Lorazepam, Zofran and Thorazine in the outpatient setting without improvement. Started on standing Baclofen inpatient and Thorazine PRN with improvement in symptoms though also with continuing hiccups. Would recommend uptitrating dose of Baclofen if hiccups continue. # Acute Renal Failure: Pre-renal given poor PO intake and ongoing lasix use in a patient who previously did not require diuretics (was started for edema after massive IVF administration with chemo). Treated with IVFs with resolution. Discontinued Furosemide, no indication for ongoing lasix use. # Hyponatremia: Hypovolumic and resolved with IVFs # Neutropenia: Chemo related s/p Neulasta ___ prior to admission, counts recovered as expected. # Malignant peripheral neural sheath tumor: Metastatic s/p resection in ___ currently C1 adriamycin/ifosfamide. Dr ___ was involved during patients admissions Transitional issues: # CONTACT: Mother ___ ___ or ___ # Recommend uptitrating Baclofen if hiccups continue
summary: You were admitted with chest pain however this seems most consistent with esophageal reflux and heartburn exacerbated by hiccups. Your medications were adjusted to include an acid suppressing agent and medications to reduce your hiccups. You also had some mild renal failure which improved with IV fluids, this occurred because you were dehydrated. It is important you eat and drink plenty of fluids to prevent this from happening, also stop taking Lasix.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ with PMH significant for cirrhosis of unclear etiology (decompensated with known visualized esophageal varices, ascites and pulmonary hypertension), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, seizure disorder, essential tremor, motorvehicular crash in ___ with resulting impaired mobility (wheelchair-bound mostly), PVD, depression, history of DVT, morbid obesity, chronic lymphedema with venous stasis changes and pancytopenia now presenting from ___ with recent admission for HCAP (treated with Zosyn) now with Proteus and E.coli bacteremia and sepsis from a presumed intra-abdominal source complicated by worsening pancytopenia, and acute on chronic anemia. # Sepsis - Recently admitted in ___ to ___ with HCAP and treated with Zosyn (ending ___ with interval improvement. Returned with fevers and found to hve Proteus and E.coli bacteremia for which he received Zosyn IV initially and transitioned to Ceftriaxone (___). Required intermittent pressor support and volume resuscitation with improvement. Source of infection presumed to be intra-abdominal and potentially from spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. C.diff negative. CXR/CT imaging notes significant ascites, splenomegaly and gallstones without obstruction. Following speciation of his bacteremia organisms he was treated with IV Ceftriaxone with a planned 14-day course. Surveillance blood cultures NGTD, TTE no endocarditis/mass. If we are unable to pursue this standard of care, oral Bactrim or cefpodoxime would be options given the AJH sensitivities. Esophageal varices noted on recent imaging, however EGD negative yesterday with evidence of portal hypertensive gastropathy vs gastritis. No indication for nadolol. # Decompensated cirrhosis - Unclear etiology at this point. No varices, however does have portal HTN and trace ascites. Previously followed by Dr. ___ ___ ___, but not recently. Work-up has included: A1AT-Ab (negative), ceruloplasmin normal, AMA normal, AFP normal, iron studies normal. Now with concern for SBP being treated empirically. summary: You were admitted to the Internal Medicine service at ___ ___ on ___ regarding management of your bacterial blood infection and recent anemia. You were transferred to the ___ from the ___. While at ___, you had a diagnostic paracentesis (tap of peritoneal fluid) to evaluate for infection and you continued IV antibiotics for a bloodstream bacterial infection from your abdomen. You also had an upper endoscopy that showed no bleeding in the esophagus or stomach. There was no sign of varices that put you at high risk of bleeding. Our Liver specialists followed you during your stay and recommended that you continue to see a hepatologist (Liver specialist) to help manage your liver disease as an outpatient. You improved and are now ready to return to ___. We recommended placement of a ___ line to allow one more week of IV antibiotics. You refused this line, therefore we recommend one week of oral antibiotics. If you have any fever, chills, or feel sick, you should be transferred to a hospital to return to IV treatment. You should have blood cultures checked ___ days after you finish treatment to be sure the infection in your bloodstream has resolved. Finally, you will need to take a low-dose daily antibiotic to prevent spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, which can lead to bloodstream infection.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ ___, mechanical fall 2 weeks ago presenting with right lower extremity pain of unclear etiology. Also with pyuria and mild hyponatremia. . . # Right leg pain: Pt with prior hx of right hip fracture, s/p ORIF with nail. Sent in by PCP for concern of dislocation or fracture, however, right hip x-rays and CT scan without evidence of fracture, dislocation or hardware malfunction. Also had right knee, right tib/fib, and right ankle x-rays that were unremarkable. summary: You were admitted for acute onset right leg pain, concerning for fracture. You underwent multiple imaging studies including CT scan and x-rays of your leg, which did not show evidence of fracture or dislocation. You also had ultrasound to exclude blood clot. Your muscle enzymes were normal and did not suggest serious muscle damage. Your pain is most likely musculoskeletal pain. You were seen by the physical therapists, and they recommended rehab. You also had low sodium levels, likely from mild dehydration. This improved with fluids. You were noted to have bacteria in your urine, although you did not have symptoms consistent with urinary tract infection. Nonetheless, you were treated with a course of antibiotics by mouth.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ yo F w/ h/o IDDM, HTN, p/w bilateral PEs from CHA w/ elevated trop, found to have multiple unprovoked bilateral segmental, subsegmental, and lobar PEs, with some concern for RH strain, transferred to the ___ for further management. summary: You were transferred here from ___ because you had been more short of breath recently and were found to have blood clots in your lungs, causing your difficulty breathing. You were treated with an intravenous blood thinner medication called heparin to prevent more clots from forming, and your breathing and oxygen levels improved. We then started you on an oral blood thinner called warfarin and also an injectable blood thinner called lovenox. You will need to continue these medication until told to stop by your primary care doctor. You will need to have your INR monitored regularly to make sure the dose of warfarin is appropriate. This will be managed by your primary care doctor.

text: Brief Hospital Course: SUMMARY STATEMENT ================== Mr. ___ is an ___ year old man with a past medical history of hyperlipidemia who presented to the ED after a transient episode of monocular vision changes at home prompting ED visit, he was admitted to the Neurology Stroke service and ruled out for acute stroke. #Vision changes: Patient reports a brief episode of right-sided vision changes at home after standing, lasting approximately 30 seconds. Described as the "right side of the room was cut in half", no true vision loss. Immediately prior to this, he experienced some dizziness and lightheadedness while sitting, when attempting to stand he drifted forward and caught himself without an actual fall. His symptoms resolved after standing. He went to the ED and his symptoms were largely resolved, his NIHSS was 0. His general and neurologic review of systems was otherwise unremarkable. His neurologic exam was notable for poor vision (right ___, left ___, blurry right-sided vision when left eye covered, full visual fields, normal fundoscopic exam, slight right arm pronation, and slightly wide based gait (see below #gait disorder). He had a brain MRI that was negative for acute or prior stroke (notably, ADC demonstrated questionable bright lesion in L basal ganglia area, per review with neuroradiology likely volume averaging, not stroke), CTA does with significant carotid atherosclerosis. While his monocular symptoms are certainly concerning for transient ischemic event, particularly an atherothrombolic event, this is unlikely given reassuring visual exam and MRI, as well as a history that does not suggest true vision loss. His serum risk factors for stroke were LDL 91, HgA1c 5.5. He was started on aspirin and his home simvastatin dose was increased. Other explanations for his vision changes include poor baseline vision given age. Low suspicion for amaurosis fugax per description of event, or temporal arteritis given normal inflammatory markers and lack of headache, temporal pain. Given low suspicion for ischemic event, ophthalmology evaluated the patient and found no occular pathology. #Gait disorder #Peripheral Neuropathy Patient with longstanding history of mild peripheral neuropathy of unclear etiology and gait instability. He is seen in as an outpatient in neurology clinic (Dr. ___. His symptoms are largely thought to be related to anxiety, as they are subjectively out of proportion to his examination findings. On admission, his gait was slightly wide based, he states this is chronic. His A1c of 5.5 does not suggest diabetic neuropathy, although he is close to pre-diabetic range. Notably, he is a daily drinker ___ beers per day), and this may be contributory. #HLD Increased home statin dose as above. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ===================== [] continue to encourage reduction in alcohol consumption [] increased simvastatin dose 20 to 40 mg QD [] initiated aspirin 81 QD
summary: You came to the hospital because you developed some vision changes at home. These symptoms were concerning for a stroke. We evaluated you with blood tests and imaging of your brain and determined that you did not have a stroke. However, we did find that you have some blockage in your arteries leading to your brain which places you at risk for future stroke. Your eyes were examined by our eye doctors and were ___ to be healthy. We started you on a new medication called aspirin which will keep your blood thin and will help prevent future strokes. We increased the dose of your home simvastatin medicatin to keep your cholesterol levels down, this will also help prevent future strokes.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Ms ___ is a ___ woman with a history of chronic back pain (was previously on narcotics contract at ___), former drug use, prior hepatitis C, depression, anxiety, and a growing lung mass, who underwent ___ biopsy of the lung mass, and is admitted for monitoring after a pneumothorax. Lungs clear bilaterally, with good air movement throughout at time of discharge. Per ___, her degree of pain seems out of proportion to what they would expect post-procedurally. Of note, may have low pain tolerance in the setting of high opioid requirement given her prior narcotic abuse. Pain improved over 24 hours with Tylenol and slow improvement in incisional site pain. Patient was discharged on the following pain regimen: Acetaminophen 650 mg PO/NG Q8H Tizanidine 4 mg PO/NG TID TraMADol 50 mg PO Q6H:PRN Pain - Severe # ACUTE DYSARTHRIA: Patient developed dysarthria in the setting of receiving multiple doses of IV Fentanyl, having ___ pain, and being very anxious about this pain. Her symptoms completely resolved within 15 minutes. Head CT without acute process. Neuro exam on admission is completely normal. Etiology was most likely due to medications and pain. TIA is possible, but seems less likely given acute resolution of symptoms. No concern for ongoing CVA. Having said this, upon consultation with neurology they recommended an MRI brain to ensure there was no metastatic disease in the setting of her lung nodule of unknown etiology. Her discharge neurologic exam demonstrated no focal neurologic deficits with normal cranial nerve exam, normal strength exam and normal gait. summary: You came to the hospital because you had a collapsed lung as a complication of your lung biopsy. You were admitted for observation and were given pain medication to help your symptoms. You received multiple chest x-rays which showed stability of your collapsed lung. You were given so much pain medicine that you were having difficulty talking and there was concern that you were having a stroke. A scan of your brain was performed which was reassuring and you were seen by our neurologists who did not feel you were having a stroke.

text: Brief Hospital Course: She was admitted to the Trauma Service. A left chest tube was placed. She was transferred to the Trauma ICU where she remained for several days. She was then changed to IV narcotics which made her sleepy. An oral pain regimen with adjunct therapy was then initiated. Dilaudid po was found to ultimately be the most helpful and least sedating for her. Given her history with chronic constipation an aggressive bowel regimen was started. A Physical and Occupational therapy evaluation was done; she was eventually cleared for home. Social work was also closely involved with patient and her family throughout her hospital stay.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Mr. ___ was admitted to the neurology stroke service. MRI demonstrated a R occipital stroke and a L vertebral dissection. He was started on a heparin drip. He was working with his neck at an unusual angle which may have been the trigger of the dissection. He does not have physical stigmata of a collagen vascular disorder. No family hx of such either. MRA brain/neck was not supportive of fibromuscular dysplasia. I discussed about whether to treat with aspirin or heparin gtt/warfarin with him (discussed ___ study results regarding management strategies for patients with stroke due to dissection). He agreed with switching from heparin gtt to aspirin. He was transitioned to aspirin. I recommended no lifting more than 20lbs at a time, no contact sports, and avoid rapid turning of the neck for the next six months. Since he has only a partial left superior quadrantanopsia, I said that he could continue to operate a motor vehicle. He should follow up with a Neuro-ophthomologist. Stroke workup was otherwise significant for: Tox screen negative Trop <0.01 Lipid panel pending Echocardiogram showed no thrombus or shunt.
summary: You were admitted to the hospital because of acute onset vision loss affecting the left upper quadrant of your vision. We found on imaging that you had a small stroke in your right occipital lobe that likely explains these symptoms. We also found a dissection (tear in the wall) of your left vertebral artery. You most likely experienced this year because of craning your neck while working. We expect that your vision loss should improve over time. We started you on a heparin drip to decrease the risk of further strokes related to this dissection. Before discharge, you were transitioned to aspirin. You may experience some continued soreness in your neck in the next few days/weeks. Be careful with movements that may further stretch or arch your neck in the future. Try not to carry more than 20 lb over your head.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ======= SUMMARY ======= ___ w/ PMH HTN, DM2, AFib (on warfarin) who presented with left leg swelling (L>R) and 2 days of left leg pain and found to have a LLE DVT iso subtherapeutic INR. Started heparin gtt and transitioned to apixaban. ACUTE ISSUES ============= #Left femoral, popliteal DVT Treatment Per records, patient has a long-standing history of atrial fibrillation but was not on anticoagulation until 2 weeks ago when he was started after a preop evaluation for cataract surgery. Patient was never therapeutic on warfarin despite increasing doses up to 15 mg daily. He presented to the ED on ___ with 3 days of worsening lower extremity swelling and left leg erythema and pain. Doppler US w/ occlusive thrombus in the mid and distal left femoral vein and popliteal vein, nonocclusive thrombus in the proximal left femoral vein and proximal left deep femoral vein. He was started on a heparin drip in the ED and vascular surgery was consulted for possible thrombectomy. Patient had good perfusion and easily palpable pulses in distal extremities and therefore vascular did not feel any need for urgent thrombectomy. Recommended medical treatment. Patient was admitted to medicine and was transitioned from heparin drip to apixaban given difficulty in achieving therapeutic INR on warfarin. Of note, apixaban has not been studied in patients weighing greater than 120 kg. However, apixaban is not lipophilic and therefore pharmacologically should not differ in patients with obesity. Did not fail warfarin as was never therapeutic on this medication. Given difficulty with achieving therapeutic INR despite very high doses, and per discussion with pharmacologist, felt that safest option was for apixaban. #AFib Per records, appears to have been diagnosed by his PCP in ___ several years back. However, patient was not started on anticoagulation at that time. Was recently started on warfarin 2 weeks ago by new PCP who saw him for a preop evaluation for cataract surgery. Will continue on apixaban as above indefinitely for a chads vasc score of 3. Continue rate control with labetalol. #LLE Cellulitis Presented with LLE erythema and warmth which is on the shin, not so much the calf. Patient without fevers, leukocytosis, signs of skin breakdown. No concern for joint involvement. Will complete 5 day course of cephalexin for presumed cellulitis. #___ #CAD s/p PCI with two stents placed No history of CHF per patient. Does have a recent TTE done ___ weeks ago which showed EF 65% w/ small area of akinesis in distal inferior/inferoseptal walls. summary: You were having leg swelling and pain and were found to have a blood clot and infection. He had an ultrasound of your lower legs which showed blood clots in your left leg. You were started on a blood thinner called heparin through your IV. You were also found to have an infection of your left leg and was started on antibiotics. Due to your difficulty achieving a therapeutic INR on warfarin, we decided to switch you to a different blood thinner called apixaban. text: Brief Hospital Course: She was admitted to the Acute Care Surgery team and underwent CT imaging of her abdomen showing closed loop obstruction or transmesenteric internal hernia complicated by small bowel ischemia. She was made NPO and given IV fluids. It was discussed with her that operative repair was indicated; she was prepped, consented and taken to the operating room on her first hospital day for exploratory laparotomy with lysis of adhesions. There were no complications. Postoperatively she progressed slowly in terms of return of bowel function. Her NG was removed on POD# 2 and she was kept NPO for 24 hours. Her diet was advanced very slowly starting with sips and eventually to solids for which she was able to tolerate. She did have urinary retention after Foley catheter removal on POD#2 requiring that her catheter be replaced. Another voiding trial was attempted on the POD#3 and she voided on her own initially. On POD #4 she was noted with very little urinary output with bladder distention and was bladder scanned for >800 cc's; the Foley was replaced again. Flomax was started as well. She was started on Unasyn for blood cultures that grew CORYNEBACTERIUM SPECIES; repeat blood cultures were sent and there was no growth as of ___. The antibiotics were discontinued on ___. Her pain was well controlled with oral narcotics and she is ambulating independently. She is being discharged to home and will follow up with her PCP and in the Acute Care Surgery clinic as scheduled. Patient will be sent home with foley in place and plan to f/u with urology as an outpatient. Appointment was provided at time of discharge. Foley care teaching was provided and patient declined ___ services.
summary: You were admitted to the hospital with an obstruction in your intestines that required an operation to alleviate. You are being discharged on medications to treat the pain from your operation. These medications will make you drowsy and impair your ability to drive a motor vehicle or operate machinery safely. You MUST refrain from such activities while taking these medications.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Pt is an ___ yo ___ woman with a h/o HTN who presents after one episode of dizziness, found to be in hypertensive urgency in the ED with second degree heart block. #Pre-syncope- After much discussion amongst the EP team, it was decided that the EKG's and telemetry appear to show ___ type I (___) second degree heart block. Interestingly, the EKG's appear largely unchanged from ___. Based on this inofrmation, it is unlikely that the episode of dizziness/pre-syncope was caused by heart block, but more likely caused by prolonged fasting for religious reasons. Further, EP discussed the possibility of a pacemaker with the pt and she declined all evaluation for pacemaker placement. #Hypertension: Pt had hypertensive urgency in the ED with systolic BP's to the 220's. Pt remained hypertensive on the floor with morning SBP's in the 220's, although the pt was completely asymptomatic and BP's consistently trended downward to SBP's in the 150's/160's in the evening without intervention, as the pt refused po medications during the day. Looking at previous ED admisions, it was apprarent that this was a chronic issue. We restarted pt on hctz 25 mg daily, losartan 100 mg and added amlodipine 5 mg daily. Coreg, which the pt was listed as taking, was held because of concern for bradycardia. On discharge pt's BP had decreased to 160/75 with the addition of amlodipine. Transitional Issues: Pt was instructed to f/u with her PCP within one week to have her BP checked and will likely will need additional anti-hypertensives for adequate control.
summary: You were admitted with dizziness and found to have an abnormality of your heart rhythm. You were evaluated by the cardiologists who felt that this rhythm was not dangerous and most likely did not cause you to feel dizzy. We spoke with you about the possibility of putting a pacemaker; however, you declined this option. While you were here you had very high blood pressures that were hard to control.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Patient is a ___ y/o woman with a PMHx significant for IDDM, HTN, gastroparesis, and CKD, p/w a 1-month worsening of 6 months of orthostasis. . ACTIVE ISSUES: . # Orthostatic hypotension: In this patient with IDDM w/ neuropathy, orthostasis is likely ___ to autonomic dysfunction, although a component of hypovolemia was initially considered. She was given 1L NS in the ED. Patient was notably orthostatic (160s/80s supine to 85/palp standing) on presentation on the floor with no signs of hypovolemia on physical exam. Treatment with fludricortisone was considered, but due to concern about lower extremity edema (which has been severe in the past), she was started on midodrine 5mg PO QAM in discussion with Dr. ___, her outpatient neurologist. Though her symptoms improved somewhat, she still was significant orthostatic, so the midodrine was titrated up to 7.5 mg q4-6h during the day. Her metoprolol tartrate 75mg PO QHS was continued and captopril 12.5mg PO QHS was started on this admission. All antihypertensives were held during the day. The head of the patient's head was elevated ___ degrees at night to help with supine hypertension. Her symptoms and orthostatics were monitored throughout her hospital course, and she was discharged with the addition of midodrine and captopril. . # Pain control: Patient complained of back pain ___ L1 vertebral fracture and leg pain ___ peripheral neuropathy. Gabapentin was discontinued on the day of admission by outpatient neurologist due to concerns about edema and decreased kidney function. She was put on a fentanyl patch and duloxetine on ___, however she developed intense leg pains that were refractory to treatment with oxycodone and tramadol. The fentanyl patch was discontinued, and gabapentin 300mg PO BID was restarted after consulting with her neurologist. The patient was discharged on gabapentin and duloxetine for pain control. She will need close follow up with Dr. ___ neurology to see if these medications are adequately controlling her pain and if gabapentin needs to be weaned again in the future. . INACTIVE ISSUES: . # Anemia ___ CKD: Patient has had a downtrending Hct (41 in ___., 37 in ___., 32 now) likely secondary to CKD. Labs show a normocytic anemia with no markers of hemolysis. Low retic of 1.1 suggests underproduction. Iron studies were WNL. We recommend consideration of Epogen as an outpatient. . # IDDM: Patient controls diabetes at home with Humalog SS and Levemir. Her blood glucose was controlled on this admission with Humalog SS and Glargine, and FBG was monitor QACHS. . # Gastroparesis: Patient controls gastroparesis at home with promethazine, which was continued on this admission. We recommend consideration of EGD and gastric emptying study as an outpatient. . # HTN: Patient controls BP at home with metoprolol. Lasix was stopped at her ___ appt on ___. We continued metoprolol before bed on this admission and added captopril before bed (see orthostatic hypotension section above). . # CKD, Stage III: Patient's Cr on admission was 2.9 with an estimated GFR of 18, slightly elevated from a baseline of 2.4-2.5. We monitored Cr daily. Her Cr trended down to 1.9 on ___. . TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: . 1. Follow up with Dr. ___ in ___ days. 2. Assess effectiveness of midodrine for her orthostasis 3. Patient was full code on this admission.
summary: You were admitted to the hospital because you were found to have low blood pressure when upright. We obtained a number of blood tests and monitored your blood pressures during your hospital course. We found that you had orthostatic hypotension likely caused by your diabetes, and we started treatment with midodrine. Some changes were also made to your pain medications. We restarted gabapentin and began cymbalta. These changes were discussed with Dr. ___ will monitor your pain levels and make changes as necessary on an outpatient basis.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ is a ___ yo right handed man with several months of increasingly frequent episodes of vertigo and nausea. Whether the patient had a central or peripheral etiology to his vertigo and diplopia remained unclear. Therefore, he underwent an extensive work-up, including an LP, MRI and CTA. All of these studies were normal (see results section) making a central etiology unlikely. He continued to improve symptomatically during his hospitalization. It was also noted that his double vision was present in both monocular and binocular vision raising the possibility that his double vision was due to primary eye issues and not directly related to his vertigo. The patient continued to do well and was discharged in good condition. He has follow-up with neurology and should continue to treat his nausea associated with dizziness symptomatically.
summary: you were admitted for vertigo and double vision. You had a normal MRI and normal blood vessel imaging as well with a CTA. Likewise your lab studies and the fluid around your brain (CSF) was normal. You're vertigo may be due to a problem in your inner ear and you should be seen by a Neurologist (Dr. ___ here at ___. You will go home on all the same medicines that you came in on. You should also consider seeing an eye doctor as your double vision may be related to dry eyes or similar.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ y/o M with NIDDM, HTN and recently diagnosed pancreatic cancer causing biliary obstruction s/p ERCP with stent who returns with nausea and decreased ability to tolerate po. #possible functional duodenal/gastric outlet obstruction #Pancreatic adenocarcinoma #Nausea/abd discomfort: mass invasion of duodenum may be causing functional gastric outlet obstruction. D/w Pt importance of nutrition and taking what he is able to tolerate and to supplement with ensure or boost if needed. Nutrition consulted. Discussed attempting a liquid diet if he is unable to tolerate solid food. Discussed symptom control with ___, simethicone, bowel regimen. Discussed case with oncology and ERCP teams. Plan for outpt onc f/u (as already arranged ___ and per ERCP team, no significant intestinal stricture noted on ERCP to intervene upon at this time. #Hyponatremia/SIADH: clinically euvolemic now and Na improved on repeat labs likely because pt was taking decreased PO. summary: You were admitted for evaluation and treatment of abdominal pain/bloating and nausea and decreased ability to eat and drink likely secondary to your pancreatic cancer and also some constipation. For this, you were evaluated by the nutritionist and we discussed using supplements such as boost or ensure if you are unable to eat and drink well. Please try to eat and drink as you are able. You may need to have a liquid or a softer diet if you feel unable to eat and drink well.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ yom with chronic indwelling foley for hypotanic bladder admitted of groin pain and suspected UTI in setting of h/o MDR UTI's. . #Groin Pain - Pt complaining of penile and groin pain, likely a source of fungal (Dermatophytic vs candidal) infection to his penis and/or catheter irritation. Evidence of UTI was questionable. Abnormalities thought to be colonization. Treatment was not continued. Pain was controlled with Tylenol and initiation of miconazole powder to the groin. Advised that he will likely have to live with bladder spasms and he should not come to the ED routinely for this. no treatment is ever rendered. unfortunately, he has been intolerant to antispasmodics. He was discharged with close follow up with his PCP. . #Positive urine culture - Most ___ patient has asymptomatic bacteruria given lack of white count, lack of fever, and chronic ESBL E coli. His symptoms seem to be related to catheter irritation. Low probability of active infection. Discussed with PCP. . #Code - DNR/DNI (confirmed with patient)
summary: You were admitted because of bacteria in the urine, but it is not uncommon to find bacteria in the urine of patients with long-term foley catheter. In this particular case, you DO NOT have a urinary tract infection. The pain in your groin is due to a fungal infection on your penis and probably also due to irritation of having a foley catheter in place all the time. Your foley was checked and there was no blockage or blood clots. You should continue with your bi-weekly foley catheter changes. Solutions ot this problem include treatment of the infection for which an antifungal powder is being prescribed. It is VERY important that you keep your groin as clean and dry as possible to treat the infection. A suprapubic catheter, as suggested by your urologist may also improve your comfort. You should discuss this with your urologist regarding details of the procedure and whether or not it may be reversible.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Mr. ___ is a ___ with history of DLBCL on R-CHOP, ESRD on HD (MWF), diastolic heart failure, and atrial fibrillation (not on anticoagulation ___ GI bleed with duodenal ulcers) admitted with weakness and dyspnea, found to have newly depressed EF to 30%. #Acute on chronic systolic HF: TTE on admission with newly depressed EF to 30% with global hypokinesis, concerning for doxorubicin-induced cardiomyopathy (although tachy-mediated cardiomyopathy also possible given new AF). Cardiology consulted, recommended continuing home meds irbesartan and metoprolol. Volume was managed with HD. He received adjusted chemotherapy due to concern for toxicity. Discharge weight: 117 kg # DLBCL: Stage IIIA large cell lymphoma, presented s/p C2 of R-CHOP. High-intermediate risk given age, performance status and multiple sites of disease with CR estimated at 56%, ___ year OS of 37%. The patient received 2 days of rituxan/bendamustine on ___ and ___. He received two doses of neupogen on ___ and ___ prior to discharge, with plan for Onc f/u on ___ to receive neulasta. # ESRD on HD (MWF): Continue home sevelamer, calcitriol, and calcium carbonate. Not on anticoagulation due to past GIB. # CAD: Continued on home metop and atorva. # IDDM: Continued on lantus 20U BID at home + HISS. # HTN: Continued on home irbesartan, metop # Hx GOUT: Continued on home allopurinol TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: ==================== - Please arrange transportation for patient to ___ on ___ for Neulasta at 12:00 ___. He should then go to his dialysis sessiona - Follow up is recommended for several scattered calcified granulomas in both lungs, as well as other tiny pulmonary nodules measuring 3 mm or less, which are not definitely calcified found on CT A/P - Consider insulin adjustment on days where patient receives dexamethasone
summary: You were recently admitted to the hospital after experiencing shortness of breath and weakness. While you were here, you were diagnosed with worsening heart failure, likely due to one of the chemotherapy medications. The heart failure was treated with medication as well as by removing fluid from your body through hemodialysis. You were also started on a new chemotherapy regimen for your lymphoma that is now complete.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ASSESSMENT: ___ yo M with h/o CAD s/p PCI, CVA, DM2 presents with Chest Pain and Neck Pain. ## Chest pain: Patient was ruled out for an acute ischemic event with two sets of negative cardiac enzymes and negative ECG changes. He had no further pain in his chest after pain resolved in the ED with NG. However, given TIMI risk score ___, pt underwent pharmacologic stress test. Stress test showed reversible defect in the inferior wall and patient underwent catheterization which showed progressive cardiac disease, however, nothing required intervention. Per cardiology team - pt shoudl be medically managed with outpatient cardiology. If he is to become symptomatic he may require CABG in future. He was continued on statin, ASA, BB, ACEI. He also received a nutrition consult for diet control. He will require more agressive managment of cholesterol and diabetes. Atenolol was increased prior to discharge to improve BP control. . ## Neck pain/Headache: Initial CT scan in the ED showed artifact that could not exclude hemorrhage. Rpt CT scan showed no change from prior. Neuro exam was unremarkable. Pain improved with low dose oxycodone. CTA also excluded vertobrobasilar thrombosis. His pain was considered to be musculoskeletal after above workup was completed. Pt was discharged on tyelnol for pain control. . ## Post discharge f/u: - f/u BP, atenolol increased to 75mg daily, titrate meds to goal BP = 120/80 - consider changing to more potent statin LDL < 70 - nutrition counseling - consider increasing metformin for improved glycemic control.
summary: You were admitted for evaluation of neck pain and chest pain. You were found to have an abnormal stress test for which you received a catheterization. The catheterization showed worsening disease but nothing which required intervention. It is important to take care of your heart by following a low sodium, low fat, low cholesterol diet. Your headache is thought to be due to a muscle pain. There was no bleed or any signs of stroke on your CT scan.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Impression: No clear etiology for his recurrent falls though no suggestion of a new disease process on his initial evaluation; I do not think his anemia is contributing. Will continue conservative management for injuries from fall and plan for further outpatient evaluation. summary: You were admitted to the hospital after a fall and found to have a broken arm. You will need to wear a sling on your left arm for 1 week until you follow up with an orthopedic surgeon in 1 week. Also you were noted to have a neck (vertebral) fracture.
