text: Brief Hospital Course: Ms. ___ is a ___ lady with a h/o cocaine and IV heroin use who was transferred from an OSH due to MRSA sepsis from endocarditis complicated by lung abscesses. She was in serious condition for much of her hospitalization, but she never decompensated into septic shock. Her hospital course was notable for recurrent sinus tachycardia and fevers to 103, management of neutrophil-predominant pleural effusions s/p thoracenteses/chest tubes, brief MICU transfer for somnolence, and brief MICU transfer for hypoxia. She improved slowly on Vancomycin IV. When her chest tubes had been removed, and she was breathing comfortably on room air, and she became afebrile for >24H, she was discharged to rehab to complete her antibiotic course. #. MRSA Sepsis: endocarditis with lung abscesses. Fever to 103 with rigors, sinus tachycardia to 140, leukocytosis to 21K, and tachypnea all represented systemic response to her infection. She grew MRSA from BCx at the OSH, but here the only (+) was the very first blood culture - all subsequent cultures were negative. Though she had no murmur on exam, with MRSA bacteremia and continued fevers, clinically fits with endocarditis. Most likely right-sided IE given that patient is IVDU, as well as the fact that she has lung emboli and no obvious left-sided peripheral emboli (head CT negative, MRI spine negative for abscess, CT abdomen negative for splenic abscess). ___ TTE's did suggest a ?right-sided vegetation but this was not seen on subsequent TTE or TEE. She continued to spike high fevers with infectious w/u negative for another cause, and these continued fevers were likely due to septic lung abscesses. Effusions were managed with drainage (see below). She was followed closely by ID who recommended continuing Vancomycin, though she was changed to Daptomycin prior to discharge due to rash (see below). Over time, she exhibited less septic physiology, and she became more comfortable. Her leukocytosis resolved completely (WBC 5.4 on discharge). She started to ambulate, breathing comfortably and was weaned to room air. She stopped spiking fevers (last fever was 102.9 at 2400 on ___, >2 days before discharge). At this point, she was discharged to rehab to complete her treatment course; proposed end-day is ___ which will complete a 6-week course. She should have weekly CBC, CHEM7, LFTs, and CPK faxed to ATTN: ___ OPAT RNs at fax# ___. She will follow-up in ___ clinic in 2.5 weeks (scheduled). #. Pleural effusions: neutrophil-predominant parapneumonic effusions, not empyema, slowly resolving. Interventional Pulmonary was following. She underwent the following procedures: ___ right thoracentesis ___ left chest tube insertion (removed) ___ left chest tube insertion (removed ___ right thoracentesis The fluid was not consistent with empyema and likely represents inflammation due to her infection. No growth from pleural fluid culture. Based on imaging, the pleural effusion size has decreased. In the future, if effusions do not resolve, she might require further procedures including possible pleurodesis. She requires repeat CT chest in ~1 month to ensure that the effusions have resolved (scheduled); she also has follow-up scheduled at ___ Interventional Pulmonary clinic. #. Rash: likely from Vancomycin. On the evening of ___ she was noted to have a mild thigh rash but by the next day she had erupted into a maculopapular blanching rash on her thighs, upper chest, back, and lower abdomen (arms were spared). Also had a follicular-pattern rash on her legs. No fever or leukocytosis. Only mildly pruritic. No mucosal involvement. It was felt that this likely represented a reaction to Vancomycin (even though it was started weeks prior). Per I.D. recommendations, she was changed to Daptomycin, which she tolerated without complication. #. Somnolence requiring MICU transfer: resolved, likely a medication effect. Patient was transferred to the ICU ___ due to being found very lethargic. Review of her medications revealed several narcoticts and benzodiazepines that were suggestive of iatrogenic somnolence. Opiods and benzodiazepines were held, with return of patient's baseline mental status. Pain consult was performed who suggested no further IV pain medications, with use of Oxycodone instead. She did not require Narcan and had no further episodes of somnolence. #. Hypoxia requiring MICU transfer: resolved, likely from lung abscesses, effusions, fever. Patient was transferred to the ICU ___ due to hypoxia (POx in the ___ on 4L NC). Was likely related to her underlying lung infection and large effusions. She underwent chest tube placement with some resolution. Also, she might have had desaturation during fevers due to vasodilation and loss of hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction leading to shunt physiology. She never required ventilatory assistance; she improved and was on 4L NC for much of her admission. By the time of discharge, she was weaned to room air but was intermittently using O2 for comfort. #. Pain control: complicated by her h/o IV heroin use and addiction. Chronic Pain Service agreed that she is not a candidate for long term opioid therapy, but she did require some IV Dilaudid in the setting of chest tube placements and other procedures. By the time of discharge, she was weaned to Oxycodone ___ PO Q4H PRN, and further down-titration and eventual cessation of narcotic pain meds would be appropriate while she is at rehab. She also continues on Tylenol, Lidocaine patch, and Gabapentin for pain control. Had some mild dyspepsia with NSAIDs but these could certainly be used as well. She would benefit from follow-up with an addiction specialist. # Anemia: unclear etiology, resolved. Hct was 29.6 on admission, had a nadir of 20.8 on ___, and was 29.6 on discharge. hemolysis/DIC workup negative and she was guaiac negative. Likely from decreased RBC production and possibly from bleeding due to procedures. She received a total of 6u pRBCs this admission. Hct was stable at the time of discharge and she had no signs of bleeding. #. Leg swelling: resolving. She had symmetric leg edema and right ankle swelling, likely from requiring large volumes of IV fluids. TTE showed good pump function. LENIs were negative and ankle film showed no fracture. With mobility and ambulation, the edema is resolving (currently trace edema upon discharge). #. Psych: initial presentation with SI, but no SI this admission. She was closely followed by Social Work this admission. She has expressed an interest in working on her mental health, mostly because she wishes to stay healthy for her son. She never had any SI or HI while hospitalized here. She should have follow-up with mental health providers after discharge. She continues on Clonazepam. #. h/o IV heroine use and cocaine use: patient wishes to stay drug-free. She was tested for HIV, HCV, and HBV which were negative. As mentioned above, she was followed closely by Social Work. She did describe herself as a "heroin addict" and hopes to be able to stay drug-free after discharge. She had no signs/symptoms of withdrawal this admission, but was treated with Clonidine initially (not continued upon discharge). She should have follow-up with mental health providers after discharge. #. ?ADHD: was a pre-admission diagnosis. She is prescribed Adderall extended release 30mg PO QAM and Adderall 30mg BID as an outpatient (confirmed with her pharmacy). Unclear indication. She requested to be restarted on Adderall and she was put on Adderall 10mg daily. She should be encouraged to wean off amphetamine-based medication given her cocaine/heroin history. #. Transitional Issues -Code status: Full Code -Emergency Contact: mother ___ ___ -Access: PICC line placed ___ -***Please remove PICC line after antibiotic course is complete.*** -Pain control: By the time of discharge, she was weaned to Oxycodone ___ PO Q4H PRN, and further down-titration and eventual cessation of narcotic pain meds would be appropriate while she is at rehab, especially since her chest tubes were removed days ago. -Fever: Last fever was 102.9 at 2400 on ___, >2 days before discharge. If at rehab she spikes a fever >101, this would be an indication for repeat blood cultures, UA/urine culture, and chest x-ray. If no source is found and fever persists, she should return to ___ for workup which could include chest CT and possible tagged WBC scan. -Rash (presumably from Vancomycin): She has a maculopapular blanching rash on her thighs, upper chest, back, and lower abdomen (arms/palms spared, no mucosal involvement). Also had a follicular-pattern rash on her legs. This rash is present at discharge, but should be monitored. -Follow-up: Infectious Disease clinic ___, Intervention Pulmonary clinic (including repeat CT) ___ -Labs/studies pending at time of discharge: none
summary: You were admitted here because of a bacterial bloodstream infection and pneumonia. The infection is likely related to your use of intravenous drugs. During your admission, you were treated for "endocarditis" (a life-threatening infection of a heart valve), with with IV antibiotics. You had fluid removed from outside the lungs. You also had a PICC line placed in your left upper arm on ___, this will be used for anibiotic delivery and drawing blood for labs. The PICC line should be removed upon completion of your antibiotics on ___. You had a rash of the lower back, abdomen and upper legs that was likely related to one of the antibiotics (Vancomycin), so you are now on a different antibiotic called Daptomycin. The Daptomycin should be continued until ___ for a total duration antibiotic therapy equaling 6 weeks. Please remember that COMPLETE cessation from IV drugs, cocaine, and all other illicit substances will be crucial to your future health. In addition, you are urged to avoid medications like Adderall and narcotic pain medications because of your history of substance abuse/dependence.

text: Brief Hospital Course: He was admitted the Trauma service. Neurosurgery and Orthopedics were consulted. He was taken to the Trauma ICU where his neurologic exam and serial head CT scans were followed and remained stable. He was started on Dilantin for seizure prophylaxis. He was taken to the operating room by Orthopedics for irrigation and debridement left iliac wing open fracture down to and inclusive of bone and open reduction internal fixation left iliac wing fracture with K-wires. There were no intraoperative complications. His scapula fracture was managed non operatively. Postoperatively he was taken back to the Trauma ICU where he remained for several days. He was later transferred to the regular nursing unit where he continued to progress. He did have pain control issues; the Acute Pain Service was consulted for epidural analgesia. An epidural catheter was placed and remained in for a couple of days and he was then changed to a long acting narcotic with shorter acting medications for breakthrough pain. For DVT prophylaxis he was started on Mini-Coumadin and will remain on this until fully ambulatory. Physical therapy evaluation was done and worked with him on a regular basis; he made significant gains and was cleared for discharge to home. Follow up instructions were provided to patient.
summary: DO NOT bear any weight on your left arm. Wear the sling for comfort. Perform pin care as directed daily. Take the low dose Coumadin "Mini-Coumadin" (which is a blood thinner use to prevent blood clots) every evening as prescribed until told to stop taking it by Dr. ___ Surgery. It is important that you continue to cough, deep breathe, use the incentive spirometer at least every hour as instructed while you are at home. You should take short walks around the house or outside at least ___ times daily.

text: Brief Hospital Course: # S/p fall, concern for fracture of transverse process of C4 vertebral body: patient was evaluated in the ED by ortho spine at which point there was no indication for surgical intervention. MRI did not show evidence of cord compression. Ortho Spine reviewed films and thought fractures were chronic. C-collar was subsequently removed. There was question of a thoracic trachea protrusion on OSH read of CT scan which was reviewed by ___ thoracic CT radiology, and felt to be narrow AP diameter and no evidence of any endotracheal mass. He underwent swallow and video swallow eval and deemed safe for ground solids and thin liquids under supervision. # HCAP: CXR revealed a RLL infiltrate concerning for HCAP. In light of negative urine culture, hypoxia (2L NC O2 requirement) and fever, patient was treated with PO levoquin and will complete a 7 day course. # Urinary tract infection: febrile to 104 initially with a grossly positive UA. Urine Cx was negative, however the patient received a dose of ceftriaxone prior to obtaining the culture. Completing treatment with levofloxacin. # Altered mental status: patient has baseline dementia, however mental status is acutely changed. Most likely delirium in the setting of urinary tract infection. LFTs, electrolytes, renal function and glucose are stable. CT head at OSH was w/o evidence of acute process. Improved but fluctuated throughout course. # Atrial fibrillation with RVR: patient with known afib, currently on metoprolol PO at home. Not on anticoagulation given risk for hemorrhage. Patient had multiple episodes of RVR the first night of admission when he was not on home metoprolol. Episodes occured in the setting of agitation and fever. Patient was rate controlled with home dose metoprolol in-house and had no further episodes of RVR. # Hypoxemia: patient has a new O2 requirement and required 2L O2 at discharge without respiratory distress. Patient underwent bilateral LENIs which did not reveal DVT. CTA was not performed due to low-risk for PE. On discharge patient's O2 requirement was 2L NC. He is discharged with home O2 and would recommend evaluation for resolution of new O2 requirement in setting of pneumonia. Recommend weaning O2 as tolerated, and ___ CXR in 4 weeks. He was noted to have desaturations during sleep, raising suuspicion for OSA. Would recommend polysomnogram and patient may cont to req O2 when sleeping. TRANSITIONAL ISSUES: -Continue Levofloxacin for 7-day course through ___. -Home O2 set up; evaluate for resolution of new O2 requirement in setting of pneumonia. Recommend weaning O2 as tolerated; ___ need O2 when sleeping--would recommend polysomnogram for suspected OSA. -Repeat CXR in 4 weeks. -Home metoprolol tartrate transitioned to Metoprolol succinate. -Liposarcoma on back of neck seen on MRI; discussed with niece, likely no intervention given overall goals of care, but to be discussed at PCP ___. -Poorly controlled rheumatoid arthritis; patient's niece states prefer to schedule own ___ with rheumatologist near assisted living facility. -Per swallow eval, recommend SLP ___
summary: You were admitted to ___ on ___ due to concern for an acute C-spine fracture and AMS which were identified in the setting of a fall. You were seen by orthopedic spine specialists who determined that it was an old fracture and safe to remove your neck brace. While admitted, you were found to be febrile and treated with antibiotics for bladder infection and pneumonia. You are continued on oxygen at home while you are recovering from your pneumonia.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ with h/o esophageal and lung CA and SBO, CAD presents with 1d of chest burning. * Chest burning: Suspected GI etiology given her history. She was ruled out for MI. Chest CT demonstrated little to cause these symptoms. Gastroenterology was consulted and performed an EGD that showed duodenitis. This is likely the cause of her symptoms. A recurrencence of malignancy was not appreciated in the EGD. Her symptoms resolved during the hospitalization. She will be continued on high dose PPI BID and follow up with her PCP for further management. Biopsies of the gastrum were performed and were pending at time of discharge. H. pylori antibody testing was performed and the test at time of discharge was pending. Upon completion of this summary, the test returned as positive. She will need further work up in the outpatient by her PCP. #Transaminitis: Patient noted to have a mild transaminitis which was trending down during her hospitalization to normal levels. Unclear etiology of this. Ultrasound was performed which showed no lesions that could address this. A repeat test should be considered in the outpatient setting. # Lung Nodule: CT of chest showed significant interval enlargement of the right upper lobe nodule highly suspicious for lung cancer until proven otherwise. This worrisome finding is to be followed up in the outpatient. # Pharyngeal Polyps: Noted in EGD. Patient asymptomatic and is scheduled to follow up with ENT for further evaluation/removal in the outpatient setting. # Atypical Kidney Findings on CT: A heterogenous right kidney was reported on CT. The Chest CT did not capture the full kidney and this should be evaluated further in the outpatient. # CAD: Patient was ruled out for MI. Continued on asa, metoprolol and statin. # HTN: Stable, continued on metoprolol, amlodipine, and lisinopril. # Glaucoma: Stable. Continued on home eye drops. # Chronic Kidney Disease: Creatinine slightly above baseline during hospitalization. Slight elevation was thought to be due to poor po intake at home. Her home atenolol was changed to metoprolol during this hospitalization as this drug is cleared renally.
summary: You came into the hospital because of chest burning. You had tests of your heart that showed no evidence for a heart attack. You were also seen by the gastroenterology specialists who performed an endoscopy. This study showed some inflammation of the small bowel (duodenitis) and also some small bumps (polyps) at the back of your throat. We recommend that you follow up with the head and neck specialists to further evaluate the polyps.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Mr. ___ is a ___ y/o male who was found unresponsive and in asystole after a suspected suicide attempt by hanging, s/p resuscitation, ROSC and TTM, with incidientally found L MCA aneurysm with planned outpatient intervention, agreeable to voluntary psychiatric admission. #S/p Cardiac Arrest EMS was called to home and patient was found in asystole after suicide attempt by hanging. Achieved ROSC after 1 round of epi and CPR. At ___ he was given mannitol for concern of cerebral edema, but re-read by radiology here showed less concern for edema. He underwent targeted temperature management then rewarmed for 72 hours as per protocol. Neurologic function improved significantly, and he was extubated on ___. He had subtle localizing defects on exam done by Neurology ___. Neurology followed and MR brain showed no evidence of anoxic injury or infarcts. We have given you a script to get this done so that your labs can be faxed to Dr. ___. Please go to ___ or the closest clinic or hospital to get this done so the heart doctors ___ follow. Your kidney function is extremely important as you are on Pradaxa and the dose can change based on your kidney function.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Assessment and Plan: ___ year old female with a history of asthma, GERD, OSA p/w asthma exacerbation precipitated by URI. . # Asthma exacerbation/brochitis/sinusitis : The patient presented with an asthma exacerbation following bronchitis/sinusitis. She did not have a fever, leukocytosis, or radiographic evidence of pneumonia. She was treated with steroids, round the clock combivent nebs, high-dose inhaled fluticasone, and zileuton. She was given dextromethorphan-guaifenisen for cough suppression. She finished a 5 day course of levofloxacin for sinusitis. She is discharged on a prednisone taper (10 mg less every 2 days) on albuterol/fluticasone inhalers and zileuton. She has close-follow-up scheduled with her PCP. She also has follow-up with her pulmonologist. . # Allergic rhinits: The patient's allergic rhinitis was stable. She is discharged on home mometasone nasal spray and Claritin-D. . # Obstructive sleep apnea on CPAP: The patient's OSA as stable and she was maintained on CPAP. . # GERD: The patient's GERD was stable. She was maintained on ranitidine, omeprazole, and ursodiol. It seems likely that she can tolerate discontinuing the ursodiol as an outpatient. . # Code: Full . # There were no outstanding labs at the time of discharge.
summary: You were admitted to the hospital for an asthma exacerbation. You were treated with your home medications plus high dose steroids and round the clock nebulizer treatments. You slowly improved over the course of your hospitalization. You will need to continue taking prednisone and all of your home inhalers. You should not wait to feel short of breath or tight before taking your albuterol inhaler. If you prefer, you can use your nebulizer.

text: Brief Hospital Course: # Altered Mental Status: The patient was initially brought in to be evaluated for possible confusion per his family. However on further questioning, he initially appeared to be at his relative baseline (blind, nearly deaf, left hemiplegia, intermittently saying ___ words with signficant stimulation but rarely oriented). An RPR was found to be mildy positive and neurosyphyllis was thought to be possibly contributing to his confusion. To this end a lumbar puncture under fluoroscopic guidance was pursued. However, due to decompensation (see below) the LP was not completed. Given the risk of a repeat LP, under guidance from the infectious disease department, it was decided to treat him for presumed neurosyphyllis. He received 2 weeks of IV ceftriaxone, completed in house, with little improvement of his mental status after his arrest. After his arrest, the patients mental status became essentially unresponsive to any stimuli. Repeat CT head and EEG showed no acute process. The patient could not receive an MRI due to a pacemaker. In consultation with neurology, his new baseline may be a result of some anoxic brain injury. . # PEA arrest: The morning of his lumbar puncture, a CXR showed complete opacification of his right lung, likely indicating a significant mucous plug at that time. At baseline, he has a large, chronic, loculated pleural effusion that compresses most of the right lung, leaving only a small section aerated. During his lumbar puncture procedure, the patient suffered a PEA arrest and was down for approximately 5 minutes. He was resuscitated with CPR. As above, after the arrest, his mental status was essentially unresponsive. His ability to protect his airway was significantly decreased. After initial extubation after his arrest, he required frequent nasal trumpet suctioning to prevent recurrent mucous plugging. Even with frequent suctioning, he had several further mucous plugging events with significant desaturations requiring acute suction. The last such event was a near respiratory arrest on the general medical floor requiring re-intubation. After lengthy discussion with his family, it was decided to place a tracheostomy to attempt to minimize further mucous plugging events and ease suctioning, as he was having significant nasopharyngeal trauma from NT suctioning. Hyocamine tabs and mucomyst nebs were added to decrease and help clear secretions. He will require frequent suctioning and close monitoring of his airway to minimize further plugging events. The family was made aware that the tracheostomy may not prevent further events and that his overall mortality in the next year is significant. They feel strongly that the patient would want to continue living no matter what the cost. Extensive discussions were held regarding goals of care and code status with no change in his full code status. The family's overall goal is to bring the patient home if at all possible. . # Respiratory Failure: As noted above, his last mucous plugging event resulted in reintubation. He is in the process of weening ventilatory support, currently on PS ventilation, ___, 40% with good respiratory mechanics. His ventilatory support should continue to be weened as tolerated with possible trach collar soon. Of note, given his poor right lung, it is unlikely that the patient will ever have a satisfactory RSBI. Sputum culture from ___ grew pseudomonas and pan-sensitive klebsiella. The patient had no evidence of actual pneumonia at that time. It was felt that the pseudomonas was likely a colonizer given that the exact same strain has been isolated from sputum cultures months prior. The klebsiella was concurrently treated during his 2 week course of ceftriaxone as above. Prior to discharge, a sputum culture was growing pseudomonas and one other gram negative rod. Again, he had no other clinical signs of pneumonia so new antibiotics were not started. Further follow of sputum culture should occur and if the patient decompensates, consideration of antibiotics treating pseudomonas should occur. . # Pyuria: Patient had a grossly positive UA. Ceftriaxone and vancomycin were given initially. Piperacillin-tazobactam was added and ceftriaxone discontinued when he became hypothermic and altered requiring ICU transfer. He was ultimately found to have a VRE urinary tract infection. He was treated with linezolid, with a recommended course of 7 days. . . # Hypothermia: On the first hospital day the patient's temperature dropped to <96 farenheit. Other vital signs were stable. Given concominant leukopenia and positive UA, this was concerning for sepsis. Blood cultures were sent, and warming blankets were placed. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit for closer monitoring in the setting of likely sepsis, his antibiotic regimen was broadened to vancomycin/zosyn. His hypothermia improved. He has been hypothermic on his last several admissions. It may be that his physiologic response to infection is hypothermia rather than hyperthermia, or he is an outlier at the lower extreme of temperature at baseline. On the floor after transfer out of the ICU he initially needed a bearhugger to maintain temperatures >96 and cultures done at that time were negative. He eventually was able to maintain temperatures ranging ___ without the assistance of a bear hugger. . #. ESRD: Family reported episode of fistula bleeding the previous day. Pressure dressing was in place on admission. Hct was decreased, possible secondary to this. Transplant surgery initially evaluated the fistula and determined that it was functional and ready for use. However, later on re-evaluation transplant surgery felt that his fistula needed revision prior to discharge. This was done and further hemodialysis should be avoided from his fistula for 2 weeks from ___. A tunnelled femoral HD line was placed for HD access until that time under ___ guidance. Dialysis was continued MWF schedule. Midodrine was added to help improve his BP prior to dialysis to assist with volume removal and to combat possible autonomic dysfunction given wide swings in blood pressure. . Enlarged Thyroid: He had chest imaging to evaluate pulmonary function. An incidential finding of thyromegaly was noted. TFTs are recommended as an outpatient. . #. Hypernatremia: This was likely secondary to hypovolemia and resolved. . #. Coronary artery disease: Aspirin, and simvastatin were continued. . #. Hypertension: Lisinopril was continued. . #. Type II DM: Oral hypoglycemics were initially held and ISS given, but restarted as his blood sugars became elevated. His lantus was increased from 12 U QHS to 16 U QHS with effect. . . #. Adrenal insufficiency- He is on 5mg prednisone daily at baseline. There was an initial concern for sepsis, thus he got high dose steroids,however ___ stim test was wnl. He was thus tapered, and returned to his home dose of 5mg daily prior to discharge. . #. Access: He has poor vasculature. Initial PICC was placed which was pulled back to midline prior to discharge as it was coming out a little. . #. CODE STATUS: Full code status was confirmed with the family.
summary: You were admitted to the hospital because you were confused, and had also been having some vomiting, and bleeding from your fistula. You were found to have an infection of your urine which was treated with antibiotics. In the setting of working up your confusion, a lumbar puncture was attempted. During this you had low oxygen levels and your heart stopped. This was likely due to mucous plugging. To attempt to prevent further plugging events, a tracheostomy was performed. Your fistula was also surgically repaired and a tunnelled dialysis catheter was placed in your groin.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Patient was admitted to the Vascular Surgery ward a day prior to scheduled right lower extremity angiogram. On admission, preoperative labs were obtained and patient kept NPO starting at midnight with adequate intravenous hydration. The following morning he was taken to the angiogram suite prior discussion of risks and benefits of the planned procedure, which the patient and health-care proxy consented to proceed with. He underwent RLE angiogram and findings included stenosis of right external iliac artery like a shelf, 2 vessel run-off (___) with distal DP reconstitution (AT w/ multiple stenoses ___. Given findings, percutaneous transluminal angioplasty was done with an 8 mm balloon to the right external iliac artery (please see Operative Note for further details). Patient tolerated the procedure well and was transferred back to the floor after a brief uneventful stay in the PACU. Patient remained alert and oriented throughout hospitalization. His pain was under control. He was started on a regular diet upon return to the floor, which was well-tolerated. All home medications were resumed and patient was started on plavix. Given appropriate response, decision was made to discharge back to nursing facility where he came from. Discharge teaching and follow-up instructions were discussed with patient and explained in detail in paperwork, with verbalized understanding and agreement with the discharge plan.
summary: You wer admitted to our institution prior to a planned angiogram to your right lower extermity. The procedure was done successfully and well-tolerated. We ballooned one of the main arteries in your right leg, which should restore proper blood flow to this extremity. You recovered nicely from the procedure and thus are ready to be discharged to the facility you came from.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ yo F w/ dementia, HTN, afib, ___ presenting with supratherapeutic INR and AMS with HCT drop of 9 points in two days and hypotension. On arrival the hospital, family wished to not pursue aggressive measures. Patient received 3 units of packed RBCs. You were in the ICU for some time where you received blood and then you were transferred to floor. text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ is a ___ female with hx of asthma, sickle cell disease (hemoglobin SS) c/b CVA on chronic transfusion protocol. with residual R sided weakness transferred for concern of biliary dilation and splenomegaly/infarct on CT after initially presenting to them with lower back pain. summary: You were admitted for evaluation of abdominal pain. You were found to have gallstones in your bile duct. These were successfully removed with ERCP procedure. We considered surgery to remove your gallbladder and gave you blood transfusion. You have decided to delay your surgery and schedule this after discharge. text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ yo man, mechanical valve, atrial fibrillation, here with subtherapeutic INR after vit K in ED on day prior for supratherapeutic INR. Reviewing records, appears that INR has been subtherapeutic with some changes to his regimen with increased dosing. Regardles, unclear etiology for extreme excursion. . # Mechanical AVR: He was started on heparin to coumadin bridge. He was reloaded with coumadin, and quickly returned to a therapeutic level by discharge, with final INR 3.1. Based on discussions with anticoagulation service, he was restarted on his home dose. The lability of his INRs was not understood, without clear precipitant. He will have repeat INR 2 days after discharge, with adjustment as needed. . # Atrial fibrillation: He was paced on EKG, and treated with coumadin/heparin as above. He was rate controlled on toprol. . # Mild encephalopathy on admission: oriented and clear on my exam. He remained stable with no further encephalopathy. He does appear to have some mild memory impairment, and I discussed with his daughter and PCP the need to have him evaluated in the drivewise program as he is continuing to drive locally. . # Diastolic CHF, chronic: euvolemic. His volume status remained stable throughout admission. . # Rheumatoid arthritis with wrist pain: Wrist appears swollen, but relatively symmetric. He was found to have subacute fractures, likely from a fall six weeks prior. He continued prednisone, methotrexate. . DVT: heparin therapeutic Elopement risk. He eloped twice, but after admission, he did not display any problems with his plan of care, and made no further attempts to elope.
summary: You were admitted because your coumadin level was too low. One day earlier, when you were seen in the ER, it was too high, and you got some medication to reverse it. You were started on a heparin drip and your coumadin level returned to its normal level. Talk to Dr. ___ referring you to a safe driving program. ___ is going to come in and pick you up.

text: Brief Hospital Course: Mr. ___ was transferred to ___ from ___ with NSTEMI on ___. On ___ he underwent a cardiac cath with POBA to RCA but unable to further expand RCA stent. On ___ he continued to experience ___ chest pain, worse with ambulation. His Ranexa was increased to 1000 mg BID and his Imdur was increased to 150 mg daily. On the AM of ___ he c/o ___ chest pain consistent with his baseline level of intermittent chest pain over the past year, not similar to the chest pain that caused him to present to ___. After his morning medications his chest pain resolved and he was able to ambulate and remain pain free throughout the day. He is discharged home with the above medication changes with a plan for scheduled PCI of RCA in 1 month.
summary: You were admitted to ___ for evaluation of your chest pain. You had a cardiac catheterization where they were able to open up some of the blockage in your right coronary artery. However, some of the blockage remains and you will need to come back in a month to have that fixed once your heart heals from the procedure yesterday. To prevent future chest pain, we increased the dose of two a medications you were already on, Isosorbide (Imdur) and Ranolazine (Ranexa). Isosorbide is increased to 150 mg daily. You will take a 120 mg tablet and a 30 mg tablet for a complete dose. Ranolazine is increased to 1000 mg twice daily. Prescriptions for these have been e-prescribed to your pharmacy.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ with hypertension and diabetes who is admitted after being discharged on ___ after resection of craniopharyngioma on ___ with central diabetes insipidus and headache. # Central diabetes insipidus: The patient has central diabetes insipidus manifesting with hypernatremia, polyuria and substantial thirst in the post-neurosurgical setting. The patient had been managed with PO demospressin on discharge. There was concern that the patient had taken her desmopressin with food after discharge, which may have interfered with the drug's absorption and led to her hypernatremia. The patient was initially given D5W IV with good response in her sodium level. Endocrinology was consulted. The patient was initially monitored with q4 hour serum sodium and urine specific gravity/osmolality checks. A foley was placed and urine output was monitored hourly. The patient was initially dosed with desmopressin when she would "break through" with >300cc of urine output per hour for two consecutive hours. Her desmopressin dosing was gradually stabilized to 0.2mg QHS, with strict instructions to not take with food. The patient was strongly encouraged to drink to thirst. Her labs were spaced out to twice daily. She still had occasional morning hypernatremia that was likely a consequence of the patient not drinking fluids overnight. When the patient was stabilized her foley was removed to reduce infection risk. The patient was discharged to rehab on 0.1mg desmopressin BID at 7am and 9pm. She was discharged with a ___ appointment in place with her endocrinologist. # Headache: The patient had a headache on admission and occasionally throughout the admission. There was initially concern for post-operative hematoma. She had a head CT scan which was not concerning to her neurosurgeons. Her headache improved with Tylenol and tramadol. Her neurologic exam was unchanged. # Bilateral Eye pain/episcleritis: On ___ the patient developed bilateral eye pain with her headaches. Her eyes were tender to the touch. Ophthalmology saw the patient. They diagnosed her with episcleritis. Her pressure in the eyes were < 12 and <10 in the R and L respectively, which was not concerning for glaucoma. She was treated with artificial tears and tobramycin-dexamethasone drops with improvement of her eye pain. Of note, the patient had poor visual fields and acuity during this admission, which per ophtho is her baseline. She was discharged with a ___ appointment with ophthalmology. - continue tobramycin-dexamethasone 0.3 %-0.1 % 1 drop OPH: Three times a day from ___ #Acute kidney injury: the patient had a creatinine bump to 1.3 on ___, up fro her baseline of 0.9. This was likely from increased urine output and relatively poor PO intake. On discharge creatinine and BUN has decreased. #Anemia: the patient had hemoglobins in the ___ range during this admission. She had no obvious source of bleeding. Regular blood draws may have been contributing. #Thrombocytopenia: Pt developed a thrombocytopenia on ___ that has been slowly downtrending. Today pt 107. Its unlikely to be infectious given afebrile, normal WBC count and no indication of infectious source. Still can be medication, acetamenophen is a common cause of thrombocytopenia and in <1% of cases Keppra can cause bone marrow suppression with thrombocytopenia. Broader differential is increased destruction or decreased production. Could be MAHA (DIC, HUS, TTP), since there is also an anemia. Had blood smear with 1+ rouleaux formation on peripheral smear; should follow up with PCP for further workup as indicated # Craniopharyngioma. The patient had her brain tumor resected on her prior admission. During this admission we continued her pituitary hormone replacement regimen as per endocrinology. In addition to her desmopressin as above, we continued lenothyroxine, prednisone, and keppra prophylaxis. # Diabetes: chronic. The patient was given an insulin sliding scale during this admission with good control of her blood sugars. # Left toe pain: Pt has about a week of tow pain on left toe, possibly with joint involvement. Tender to palpation, not erythematous, hard to tell whether it is warm to palpation due to warm compress. Could be gout, but unlikely infectious. - Continue to use warm compress - Increased dose of acetaminophen ***TRANSITIONAL ISSUES*** - 0.1mg Desmopressin BID at 7am and 9pm on empty stomach - continue to monitor electrolytes once daily - encourage PO fluid intake - levothyroxine 50mcg at 6am on empty stomach - Appointment with Dr. ___ endocrine ___ - f/u appointment at the ___ clinic on ___ - patient has anemia and thrombocytopenia with 1+ rouleaux formation on peripheral smear; should follow up with PCP for further workup as indicated - please follow up with outpatient iron labs - started iron supplements - monitor toe pain, treat pain with Tylenol - ___ with ophthalmology for episcleritis - continue tobramycin-dexamethasone 0.3 %-0.1 % 1 drop OPH: Three times a day from ___ - Patient should not drive until she has had formal visual acuity and visual field testing performed at ophthalmology appointment - Contact: ___ ___ - Code: Full
summary: You were ___ to ___ after going to rehab with a headache and high sodium levels. We re-scanned your head and our neurosurgeons were not concerned. Our endocrinologists were involved and adjusted the dosing of your desmopressin. You also had some eye pain. Our ophthalmologists evaluated you and you did not have glaucoma. They recommended eye drops to decrease inflammation. Our eye doctors and ___ would like to see you as an outpatient. We made appointments for you that are listed below. It is very important to drink when you're thirsty! This will help keep your sodium levels normal.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ year old female admitted to Acute Care Surgery Service after a fall down stairs while intoxicated resulting in a Grade 3 liver laceration, perinephric hematoma, right ___ rib fx, right humerus close fx (s/p reduction). text: Brief Hospital Course: Thrombophlebitis: Despite an extensive work-up, no specific focus of infection was identified. This was partly confounded by the initiation of antibiotics early in her hospitalization, but even the culture data obtained prior to antiobiotic therapy remained negative. MRI/MRA of the left arm and shoulder were read as "dilated and thrombosed left cephalic vein throughout its visualized course, with extensive surrounding edema suggesting thrombophlebitis." Transplant surgery attempted a thrombectomy, but was unsuccessful. They did not feel that there was evidence of infection in or around the thrombus and felt that her fevers were likely related to her significant clot burden. They recommended discontinuation of antibiotics and not starting anticoagulation. We explained the warning signs of infection and asked that she follow her symptoms closely and call or return if she develops fevers, swelling or pain.
summary: You were admitted for a fever after hemodialysis and pain with your AV fistula. You were treated for a probable line infection and for an infection of your AV fistula clot (thrombophlebitis) with antibiotics called daptomycin and gentamicin, which you tolerated well without reaction. You also had an MRI of left shoulder/arm due to pain and the AV fistula infection, which showed findings consistent with inflammation of the clot in the AV fistula (thrombophlebitis). Transplant surgery was consulted but did not recommend any surgery initially but then recommended removal of the AV fistula clot (thrombectomy), however, they could not succesfully remove your AV fistula clot since it was too large in its extension. After the surgery there were no other further recommendations for treatment of this clot since the clot was not infected and was in a superficial area (as opposed to a deep area). You also had your regularly scheduled hemodialysis on ___ and ___. You should attend your next dialysis as normally scheduled on ___ (___). You will not require any antibiotics, anticoagulation or other medicines for your clot. There are no new changes to your medications.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ ___ speaking h/o HTN, hyperlipidemia, prostate cancer, admitted to the MICU with CAP and sepsis, and found to have a mass in right lung apex. . # Community acquired pneumonia/sepsis: Given patient's admission x-ray, community acquired pneumonia was considered the most likely cause for his symptoms and hypotension. Blood and urine cultures were negative. Patient was begun on a 10 day course of levofloxacin and was discharged with good ambulatory oxygen saturations on room air. . # Acute renal failure: Patient was in acute renal failure with elevated creatinine of 2.3 on admission. He received IV fluids and antibiotics for septic pneumonia, and his creatinine returned to baseline. . # Falls: Patient's falls were considered likely secondary to infection and sepsis. CT head on admission was negative for ICH, and he received physical therapy while inpatient. . # Hypertension: Patient presented with hypotension, and his home regimen of antihypertensives were initially held. On transfer to the floor he was borderline hypertensive and outpatient antihypertensive regimen resumed including nifedipine. Atenolol stopped and he was changed to metoprolol given acute renal failure on admission. . # Lung mass NOS: CXR on admission revealed a rounded nodule at right apex concerning for malignancy. CT chest demonstrated a 3.5 cm mass abutting pleura in posterior segment of RUL. Radiology recommending characterization with PET CT. the patient was provided with a PET CT appointment and given instructions on preparing for the exam. Follow-up was arranged as an outpatient. . # Prostate cancer: Patient's history of known prostate cancer was considered a possible source of his new lung mass. Patient was continued on doxazosin, with PSA less than 0.1. . # Full code
summary: You were admitted to the hospital because you were confused, falling and having fevers. You were found to have a pneumonia, you were treated with antibiotics, and you improved. You were also found to have kidney failure. Later, you were found to have a mass in your right lung. You had a CT scan that confirmed the mass and its location. We will be referring you to workup this mass as an outpatient; please see below for information on the appointments for the workup.

Your blood counts are low but has stablized. Please take the pantoprazole twice a day. Do not take anymore NSAIDS such as Ibuprofen, Aleve, Motrin for pain. Please take only Tylenol as needed for now until you can speak to you primary care physician. Please have your primary care physican test for stool H. Pylori antigen. text: Brief Hospital Course: Mr. ___ is a ___ year old gentleman with history of CKDIII, prostate CA, HTN, glaucoma, multiple admissions for FTT who presents from PCP's office with altered mental status, weakness, brief hypotension that resolved with IVF. MRI brain negative for acute process. Patient found to have E. coli UTI treated with ciprofloxacin. Patient was found to be malnourished with poor PO intake. Nutrition recommended g tube placement but this was not within patient or ___ daughter's goals of care. Physical therapy evaluated patient and recommended acute rehabilitation but patient adamantly refused rehabilitation and requested to go home. Met with patient, daughter, and palliative care team and patient decided to return to home with home hospice. Patient decided that he would want resuscitation (FULL CODE) but would not want to be hospitalized. Patient completed a MOLST form prior to discharge to reflect this and was discharged to home with home hospice. #Weakness: Patient with generalized weakness requiring assistance for all transfers, R>L sided weakness on exam. No evidence of acute infarct or stroke on MRI brain, only signs of chronic small vessel disease. ___ weakness most likely secondary to poor PO intake given cachectic appearance, low body weight, dehydration. Patient and his daughter would not be interested in g tube or artificial feeding at this time. ___ has recommended acute rehab though patient has declined at this time, ___ lift ordered per ___ recommendations to help with home transfers. #Altered Mental Status: Patient with intermittent altered mental status, has appeared dry and improved with IVF x2 consistent with poor PO intake and dehydration. He has evidence of chronic small vessel changes on MRI but no new stroke to explain mental status changes. Also consider component of delirium given waxing and waning nature. ___ be component of infectious etiology given Ecoli UTI which we treated as below. #UTI: Patient with +UA, urine cultures with E.coli. text: Brief Hospital Course: ASSESSMENT: ___ is a ___ year old female with a history of asthma, emphysema, CV disease, high BP, high cholesterol, NIDDM, R breast cancer, who presents with chest pain concerning for possible unstable angina, as well as shortness of breath. PLAN: *Chest pain: Patient presented with acute onset of chest pressure, jaw pain and arm pain. Although she generally has about ___ episodes a week that are relieved by nitroglycerin, this episode was notable for no decrease in pain with treatment. Additionally, the specific symptoms of jaw pain and chest pressure are not present with her usual episodes of chest pain. Her labs are notable for negative troponin, that was trended and remained negative. Stress test showed no anginal symptoms or ischemic ST segment changes. Nuclear stress test was performed as well which showed no new changes in heart function or perfusion. Given the lack of F/C, time course of chest pain, and symptoms, suspect that her chest pain symptoms were not attributable to flow-limiting coronary disease. She did not have a recurrence of pain, and her vital signs and telemetry were monitored and stable throughout admission. She will follow up with her PCP for further management. . *Shortness of breath: Patient noted shortness of breath on admission. Her D-Dimer in the ED was negative, given her low Well's criteria score, and low clinical suspicion, no additional tests for PE were performed as this effectively r/o thromboembolic process. No recent history of URI, so less likely to be infectious. Given the timing of SOB coinciding with chest pain, likely cardiac or COPD exacerbation. On the floor, O2 sat have been recorded in ___ without O2. Prior to discharge, it was determined that with exertion, O2 min on RA --> 83, O2 min on 1L --> 88, O2 min on 2L --> 90. ABG showed pH of 7.39, pO2 of 72, pCO2 of 42. Likely due to chronic COPD. Pulmonology saw her and thought this is most likely due to her long-standing COPD that has likely been chronic, and that this hypoxia is most likely not a new event. They recommended an ECHO with bubble study to rule out right to left shunting as an outpatient and recommended home O2. On day of discharge, patient was comfortable, 96% on 2L O2, without chest pain or shortness of breath. . *Anemia: patient has anemia on CBC with most recent Hct of 31.7. He did not produce a urine sample for testing for methadone and other CNS depressants. Given his return to normal mental status on HD#2 it is highly likely that his period of AMS was due to overmedication. He was counseled to avoid excessive narcotic use and combinations with other drugs. He was prescribed a bowel regimen given his chronic opiate use. Chronic Diagnoses: #Chronic Hepatitis C: Possibly resolved. Hep C antibody positive ___. Viral load negative at ___ in ___, though it is unclear if he was treated or cleared the infection himself. summary: You were admitted to ___ after sustaining an injury that resulted in a left sided pneumothorax. What is a collapsed lung? A collapsed lung, also called a pneumothorax, happens when air enters the space between your rib cage and one of your lungs. The air causes all or part of the lung to collapse. It is then hard to breathe normally and your body gets less oxygen. A collapsed lung can be life-threatening. In some cases, the air collecting around the lung can completely collapse the lung and put pressure on the heart. Then the heart cannot pump normally. A collapsed lung may be caused by an injury to the chest, such as a car accident, stab or bullet wound, or broken ribs. It may also be caused by lung damage from chronic lung diseases, electric shock, or near drowning. Sometimes there is no known cause for the lung to collapse. This is called a spontaneous pneumothorax.

text: Brief Hospital Course: ___ is a ___ y/o M h/o advanced dementia with chronic urinary catheter in place with hx in ___ of coagulase negative staph bacteremia on suppressive Bactrim presenting from home with diarrhea, lethargy, decreased responsiveness, found to have fungal and streptococcus anginosus septic shock likely ___ multifocal aspiration pneumonia requiring pressors and IVF, with stable blood pressures and improvement in clinical status now discharged from MICU to floor. summary: You were admitted to ___ for evaluation of intermittent right leg weakness. Your initial CT scan showed a small area of bleeding on the surface of your brain, and a follow up MRI of your head showed signs of an old stroke as well as multiple small new strokes. As your blood vessel imaging did not show signs of significant vascular disease, it is likely that the clots leading to your strokes came from your heart. In discussing with your outpatient cardiologist, you were previously found to have a connection between your heart chambers (patent foramen ovale - PFO) that may predispose you to strokes. An ultrasound of your heart (transthoracic echocardiogram) was performed with prelim read confirming the PFO with no other valvular abnormalities. We strongly recommended a follow-up endoscopic study (transesophageal echocardiogram), but you instead elected to have this procedure done as an outpatient. This was discussed with your cardiologist, who will follow up with you to schedule the transesopagheal echocardiogram, ultrasound studies of your legs, and heart rhythm monitoring. In the meantime, we again started you on aspirin and a cholesterol medication (atorvastatin) to reduce your risk of future strokes.
